div1.p: THE Coffee-House Politician; OR, THE JUSTICE Caught in his own TRAP.
A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Lincoln's-Inn Fields.
LONDON: Printed for J. WATTS, at the Printing-Office in Wild-Court near Lincoln's-Inn Fields. MDCCXXX.

lg.l: IN ancient Greece, the Infant Muse's School,
Where Vice first felt the Pen of Ridicule,
With honest Freedom and impartial Blows
The Muse attack'd each Vice as it arose:
No Grandeur could the Mighty Villain screen
From the just Satyr of the Comick Scene:
No Titles could the daring Poet cool,
Nor save the great Right Honourable Fool.
They spar'd not even the Aggressor's Name,
And Publick Villany felt Publick Shame.
Long hath this gen'rous Method been disus'd,
For Vice hath grown too great to be abus'd;
By Pow'r, defended from the Piercing Dart,
It reigns, and triumphs in the Lordly Heart;
While Beaus, and Cits, and Squires, our Scenes afford,
Justice preserves the Rogues who weild the Sword;
All Satyr against her Tribunal's quash'd,
Nor lash the Bards, for fear of being lash'd.
But the Heroick Muse who sings To-night,
Through these neglected Tracks attempts her Flight:
Vice, cloath'd with Pow'r, she combats with her Pen,
And fearless, dares the Lyon in his Den.
Then only Reverence to Pow'r is due,
When Publick Welfare is its only View:
But when the Champions, whom the Publick arm
For their own Good with Pow'r, attempt their Harm,
He sure must meet the general Applause,
Who 'gainst those Traytors fights the Publick Cause.
And while these Scenes the conscious Knave displease,
Who feels within the Criminal he sees,
The Uncorrupt and Good must smile, to find
No Mark for Satyr in his Generous Mind.
RAPE upon Rape! what Author ever chose
A Name so sure to make the Fair his Foes!
And, Ladies, I can read in all your Faces,
Our Author is not much in your good Graces;
But pray, confess, does all this Fury fall,
Because these Scenes Rape upon Rape we call?
Or is it—that we have no Rape at all?
Our modern Beaus in Vigour are so hearty,
And modern Dames so very full of Vartue,
So scarce immodest Women, Men so urging,
A Rape's almost as common as a—Virgin.
Oh! may our Youth whose Vigour is so parlous,
To Italy be wafted with Don Carlos;
There should one Victory but give them Scope,
They would not leave one Maidenhead for the Pope;
Or should some new Pope Joan the Chair possess,
They'd play the Devil with her—Holiness.
Rape upon Rape should follow Blows on Blows,
And New Rome fall, by what the Old arose.
Lucretia surely, tho' her Fame has sounded,
With Ardour for her Country ne'er abounded;
Who so abhorr'd, what had her Country founded.
Heathenish Wretch! the Pious Christian Wife,
Tho' ravish'd, still contents herself with Life:
So zealous from Self-Murther we refrain,
We live, tho' sure of ravishing again.
What need has She of Penance or Repenting,
Who undergoes it all without consenting?
She sure, tho' with her Sword Lucretian swagger,
Requires a Cordial rather than a Dagger.
But may no fear of Ravishing affright
The beauteous kind Spectators of To-night;
Safe to your Husbands Arms may you escape,
And never know that dreadful thing, a RAPE.

div1.head: RAPE upon RAPE; OR, The JUSTICE caught in his own TRAP.

div3.head: SCENE I.
SCENE A Parlour in Politick's House. A Table spread with News-Papers. Chairs.

sp.speaker: HILARET.
sp.p: WELL, Cloris, this is a mad Frolick. I am horridly frighted at the Thoughts of throwing my self into the Power of a young Fellow.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: It is natural to us to be frighted at first: I was in a little Terror my self on my Wedding-Day, but it went all off before the next Morning; a Husband, like other Bugbears, loses all his Horror when we once know him thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But if he should not prove a good Husband—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Then you must not prove a good Wife—If he keeps a Mistress, do you keep a Gallant; if he
stay out with his Friends at a Tavern, do you be merry with your Friends at home.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You give fine Advice indeed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Madam, it was such as I followed my self. I had a Rogue of a Husband that robbed me of all I had, and kept a Mistress under my Nose: but I was even with him: for it hath been ever my Opinion that a Husband, like a Courtier, who is above doing the Duties of his Office, should keep a Deputy.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But suppose you had been in Love with your Husband?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why so I was, Madam, as long as he deserved it: but Love, like Fire, naturally goes out when it hath nothing to feed on.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, if it be possible to be assured of a Lover's Sincerity, I think I may be assured of Constant: at least it is adviseable to persuade my self of his Truth whom I should Love, tho' he wanted it:—Ah, Cloris! you may as easily remove a Rock as a Woman's Passion—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: And yet it is very often built on a sandy Foundation.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Love is the same, whatever be its Object: We as often like Men for imaginary as real Perfections; we all look through a Prismatick Glass in Love, and whatever Beauties we have once fancied, we never lose the Opinion of—our Amorous Faith is as implicit as our Religious.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: If I have any Judgment in Mankind, and I am sure I have had some Experince in them, your Passion could have been no where better fixed: Capt. Constant hath all the Qualities any Woman can desire. He hath Youth, Beauty, Vigour, Gallantry, Constancy, and as Mr. Cowley says, a long &c.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Ay there it goes, tick tack, tick tack, like the Pendulum of a Clock. What Mischief are you hatching,
hey?—It is impossible that two Women should be together without producing Mischief.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I always thought a Man and Woman the more likely to produce Mischief: and yet I think them the properer Company.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I suppose you will tell my Daughter so too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Indeed Papa she need not: for I was always of that Opinion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You was! but I shall prevent your Wishes—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You may be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I do not believe the Head of Cardinal Fleury can be more perplexed, than mine is with this Girl. To govern your self, is greater than to govern a Kingdom, said an old Philosopher; and to govern a Woman is greater than to govern twenty Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wish you would not perplex your self with Cardinals or Kingdoms, I wish you would mind your own Business, instead of the Publick's; dear Papa, don't give your self any more trouble about Don Carlos, unless you can get him for a Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not if I were a King. I will make you a little sensible who Don Carlos is.—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, I do not understand one Word of your Politicks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am sorry you do not—A News-Paper would be a more profitable Entertainment for you than a Romance. You would find more in one half Sheet, than in the grand Cyrus.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: More Lies very probably—You know I do read the Home Paragraphs in the Whitehail Evening Post: and that's the best of them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If you would be informed in these Matters, you must read all that come out: about forty every Day, and some Days fifty: and of a Saturday about fourscore. Would you continue in such a Course but one Twelvemonth, I do not question but you might know as much of Politicks as—any Man that comes to our Coffee-house. And I had rather see you a Politician, than a Woman of Quality.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If I may speak freely, it would have been better for me that you had been less a Politician.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You are deceived, very much deceived: but some Fool hath put this into your Head. You may live to see me one of the greatest Men in England. Did I not say at the Siege of Gibraltar, that within one three Years, we should see whether we should have Peace or no. And yet I am an Ignoramus; I know nothing I warrant you: I had better have continued a Merchant no doubt: but then what had become of my Projects? where had been all those twenty different Schemes which I have now ready to lay before the Parliament, greatly for my own Honour and the Interest of my Country? Harkye, I have contrived a Method to pay off the Debts of the Nation, without a Penny of Money.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And you will not get a Penny by it, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, no, no certainly: tho' I would not take twenty thousand Pounds for the Advantage which will arise to me from it. It hath lain these three Years in a Friend's Hands of mine of the House of Commons; who assured me not many Days ago that it should be taken shortly into Consideration, tho' he believed it could not be this Sessions.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nor this Age, I am confident.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And how do you think it is to be compassed! why, by procuring a Machine to carry Ships by Land about a hundred Miles: and so prosecute the East-India Trade, thro' the Mediterranean.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wish you Success, Sir: but I must take my leave of you, for it grows very late: so good-Night, Papa.

I cannot rest for these Preparations of the Turks. what can be their Design!—It must be against the Emperor.—Ay, ay, we shall have another Campaign in Hungary. I wish we may feel no other
effect from them—should the Turkish Gallies once find a Passage through the Straights, who can tell the Consequence. I hope I shall not live to see that Day

div3.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: We are all undone, Neighbour Politick! all blown up! all ruined!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Protect us—what is the Matter? No News of the Turks, I hope!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: An Express is arrived with an Account of the Dauphin's Death.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Worse and worse—this is a finishing Stroke indeed! Mr. Dabble, I take this Visit exceeding kind—pray be pleased to sit: we must confabulate on this Important Accident.—Pray light your Pipe—I wish this may not retard the Introduction of Don Carlos into Italy.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I wish it may.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I wish Don Carlos do not prove a more formidable Power than is imagined.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don Carlos a formidable Power, Mr. Dabble?

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I wish we do not find him so.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I look on Don Carlos to be an errant Blank in the Affairs of Europe—and let me observe to you, the Turks give me much greater Uneasiness than Don Carlos can: What the design of their Preparations can be, is difficult to determine—this I know, that I know nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I think we have no need to travel so far for Apprehensions, when Danger is so near us: the Prospect of Affairs in the West is so black, that I see no Reason to regard the East: the monstrous Power which Don Carlos may be possessed of by the Death of the Dauphin—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Rather, the monstrous Power which the Emperor may be possessed of.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: The Emperor—ah!—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don Carlos truly.

div3.stage: Both shake their Heads at one another.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I would fain ask one Question, Mr. Politick. Prav how large do you take Tuscany to be?—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How large do I take Tuscany to be—let me see—Tuscany, ay; how large do I take it to be—hum—Faithful!—bring some more Tobacco. How large do I take it to be—why truly I take it to be about as large as the Kingdom of France—or something larger.—

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: As large as the Kingdom of France—you might as well compare this Tobacco-Pipe to a Canon. Why Tuscany, Sir, is only a Town, a Garrison to be admitted into Tuscany; that is, into the Town of Tuscany—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I will convince you of your Error—here, Faithful, bring a Map of Europe hither

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I did not think, Mr. Politick, you had been so ignorant in Geography.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I believe I know as much as you, or any one, of it.

sp.speaker: Faith
sp.p: Sir, Sir, your Daughter is gone out of the House, no one knows whither.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And give me leave to tell you, Sir, I wish your own Ignorance in publick Affairs doth not appear to our Cost.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Sir, I wish you would send for the Map.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Map me no Maps, Sir, my Head is a Map, a Map of the whole World.—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, your Daughter—

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: If your Head be a Map, it is a very erroneous one.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I would not have called Tuscany a Town in a Coffee-House, to have been Master of it.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Nor I have compared it to France, to have been King of both.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Great News, Gentlemen, all's safe again.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: More Deaths?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: An Express is arrived with a certain Account of the Dauphin's being in good Health.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: This is good News indeed.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Is there a certain Confirmation?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Very certain—I came this moment from the Secretary's Office.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Porer, you are the welcomest Man alive—This News makes me the happiest Creature living.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I wish, Sir, my News may not prevent it—Your Daughter, Sir, Miss Hilaret, is gone out of the House, and no one knows whither▪

sp.speaker: Pol
sp.p: My Daughter gone! that is some allay to my Happiness, I confess: but the loss of twenty Daughters would not balance the Recovery of the Dauphin—However, Gentlemen, you will excuse me, I must go enquire into this Affair.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Be not concerned at any thing, after what you have heard: let the Private give way to the Publick ever.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not leave us yet, and sneak away to some nasty little Whore? A Pox confound them, they have spoiled so many of my Companions, and forced me to Bed sober at three-a-Clock in the Morning so often—that if the whole Sex were going to the Devil, I would drink a Bumper to their good Journey.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: And I would go thither along with them. The dear charming Creatures! Woman! It is the best Word that ever was invented. There's Musick, there's Magick in it. Mark Anthony knew well to lay out his Money, and when he gave the World for a Woman—he bought a lumping Pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: If he had given it for a Hogshead of good Claret, I would have commended the Purchase more.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Wine is only the Prologue to Love: it only serves to raise our Expectation. The Bottle is but a Passport to the Bed of Pleasure. Brutes drink to quench their Appetites—but Lovers to enflame them.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: 'Tis Pity the generous Liquor should be used to no better a Purpose.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: It is the noblest use of the Grape, and the greatest Glory of Bacchus is to be Page to Venus.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Before I go into a Tavern again with a Man who will sneak away after the first Bottle, may I be cursed with the odious sight of a Pint as long as I live: or become Member of a City-Club where Men drink out of Thimbles, that the Fancy may be heightened by the Wine, about the same time that the Understanding is improved by the Conversation: I'll sooner drink Coffee with a Politician, Tea with a fine Lady, or 'Rack Punch with a fine Gentleman, than thus be made a Whetstone of, to sharpen my Friends Inclinations, that some little Strumpet may enjoy the Benefit of that good Humour which I have raised.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why, thou art as ill-natured and as angry as a Woman would be, who was disappointed in the last Moment, when her Expectations were at the highest.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And have I not the same Cause?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Truly, honest Nol, when a Man's Reason begins to stagger, I think him the properest Company for the Women: One Bottle more, and I had been fit for no Company at all.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Then thou hadst been carried off with Glory.—An honest Fellow should no more quit the Tavern while he can stand, than a Soldier should the Field; but you fine Gentlemen are for preserving your selves safe from both, for the Benefit of the Ladies.—'Sdeath! I'll use you with the same Scorn that a Soldier would a Coward: So, Sir, when I meet you next, be not surprized if I walk on the other side the way.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Nay, pr'ythee, dear Silenus, be not so enraged; I'll but take one refreshing turn, and come
back to the Tavern to thee. Burgundy shall be the Word, and I will fight under thy Command till I drop.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Now thou art an honest Fellow—and thou shalt Toast whomsoever thou pleasest.—We'll bumper up her Health, till thou dost enjoy her in Imagination. To a warm Imagination there is no Bawd like a Bottle. It shall throw into your Arms, the soberest Prude or wildest Coquet in Town; thou shalt rifle her Charms, in spight of her Art. Nay, thou shalt encrease her Charms more than her Art: and when thou art surfeited with the luscious Pleasure, wake cooly the next Morning, without any Wife by your side, or any fear of Children.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What a luscious Picture hast thou drawn!

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And thou shalt have it, Boy! thou shalt triumph over her Virtue, if she be a Woman of Quality—or raise her Blushes, if she be a common Strumpet. I'll go order a new Recruit upon the Table, and expect you with Impatience—Fill every Glass.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sure, this Fellow's whole Sensation lies in his Throat: for he is never pleased but when he is swallowing: And yet the Hogshead will be as soon drunk with the Liquor it contains, as he. I wish it had no other Effect upon me. Pox of my Paper Scull! I have no sooner buried the Wine in my Belly, than its Spirit rises in my Head—I am in a very proper Humour for a Frolick; If my good Genius, and her evil one would but send some lovely Female in my way—Ha! the Devil hath heard my Prayers.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Was ever any thing so unfortunate! to lose this Wench in the Scuffle, and not know a step of the Way—What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: By all my love of Glory, an Adventure.

sp.speaker: Hil
sp.p: Ha! who's that? who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb
sp.p: A Cavalier, Madam, a Knight-Errant rambling about the World in quest of Adventures. To plunder Widows, and ravish Virgins; to lessen the Number of Bullies, and encrease that of Cuckolds, are the Obligations of my Profession.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wish you all the Success so worthy an Adventurer deserves.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But hold, Madam, I am but just sallied, and you are the first Adventure I have met with.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let me go I beseech you, Sir, I will have nothing to say to any of your Profession.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That's unkind, Madam: for as I take it, our Professions are pretty nearly allied, and like Priest and Nun, we are proper Company for one another.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Profession, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I believe I am no Stranger to the honourable Rules of your Order. Nay, 'tis probable I may know your Abbess too; for tho' I have not been in Town a Week, I am acquainted with half a Dozen.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nothing but your Drink, Sir, and Ignorance of my Quality, could excuse this Rudeness.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: (Whu— [whistles] Ignorance of your Quality! The Daughter of some Person of Rank, I warrant her) [Aside] Look'e, my Dear, I shall not trouble my self with your Quality: It is equal to me, whether your Father rode in a Coach and Six, or drove it—I have had as much Joy in the Arms of an honest Boatswain's Wife, as with a Relation of the Great Mogul.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You look, Sir, so much like a Gentleman, that I am persuaded this Usage proceeds only from your mistaking me. I own it looks a little odd for a Woman of Virtue to be found alone in the Street, at this Hour—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yes it does look a little odd indeed.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But when you know my Story, I am confident you will assist me, rather than otherwise. I have this very Night escaped with my Maid from my Father's House; and as I was going to put my self into the Hands of my Lover, a Scuffle happening in the Street, and both running away in a Fright to avoid it, we unluckily separated from each other—Now, Sir, I relie on the Generosity of your Temper to assist an unhappy Woman, for which you shall not only have my Thanks, but those of a very pretty Fellow into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am that very pretty Fellow's very humble Servant. But I find I am too much in Love with you my self, to preserve you for another: Had you proved what I at first took you for, I should have parted with you easily; but I read a Coronet in your Eyes: (she shall be her Grace if she pleases, I had rather give her a Title than Money)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, now you mistake me as widely as you did at first.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nay, by this Frolick, Madam, you must be either a Woman of Quality, or a Woman of the Town—Your low mean People, who govern themselves by Rules, dare not attempt these noble Flights of Pleasure. Flights only to be reached by those who boldly soar above Reputation.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This is the maddest Fellow.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: So, my Dear, whether you be of Quality or no Quality, you and I will go drink one Bottle together at the next Tavern.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I have but one Way to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Come, my dear Angel. Oh! this dear soft Hand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Could I but be assur'd that my Virtue would be safe.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No where safer. I'll give thee any thing in Pawn for it—(but my Watch)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And then my Reputation—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: The Night will take Care of that—Virtue and Reputation! these Whores have learnt a strange Cant since I left England.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But will you love me always?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh! for ever and ever, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But will you—too.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yes, I will—too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Will you promise to be civil?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh! yes, yes; (I was afraid she would have asked me for Money.)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, then I will venture—Go you to that corner Tavern, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Excuse me, Madam, I know my Duty better—so if you please, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I insist on your going first.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And so you'll leave me in the Lurch: I see you are frighted at the Roughness of my Dress; but foregad I am an honest Tar, and the Devil take me if I bilk you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why then, Madam, here is a Pound of as good Tea as ever came out of the Indies; you understand that, I hope.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I shall take no Bribes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Refuse the Tea! I like you now indeed; for you cannot have been long upon the Town, I'm sure. But I grow weary with Impatience. If you are a modest Woman, and insist on the Ceremony of being carried, with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, do not proceed to Rudeness.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: In short, my Passion will be dallied with no longer. Do you consider, I am just come on Shore, that I have seen nothing but Men and the Clouds this half Year, and a Woman is as ravishing a Sight to me as the returning Sun to Greenland. I am none of your puisny Beaux, that can look on a fine Woman, like a surfeited Man on an Entertainment. My Stomach's sharp, and you are an Ortelan; and if I do not eat you up, may salt Beef be my Fare for ever.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I'll alarm the Watch.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
You'll be better natur'd than that. At least. to encounter Danger is my Profession; so have at you,
my little Venus—If you don't consent, Ill ravish you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Help there! a Rape, a Rape!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hush, hush, you call too loud, People will think you are in earnest.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Help, a Rape!—

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: That's he there, seize him.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Stand off, ye Scoundrels!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, you should have stood off—Do you charge this Man with a Rape, Madam?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am frighted out of my Senses—

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: A plain Case!—the Rape is sufficiently proved—what, was the Devil in you, to ravish a Woman in the Street thus?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! dear Mr. Constable, all I desire is, that you would see me safe home.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Never fear, Madam, you shall not want Evidence.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: (Nay, if I must lodge with these Gentlemen, I am resolved to have your Company, Madam.) Mr. Constable, I charge that Lady with threatning to swear a Rape against me, and laying violent Hands upon my Person, whilst I was inoffensively walking along the Street.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: How! Villain!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Madam, you shall be made a severe Example of. The Laws are come to a fine Pass truly, when a Sober Gentleman can't walk the Streets for Women.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Sir, don't believe him.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, as we have but your bare Affirmation on both Sides, we cannot tell which Way to incline our Belief; that will be determin'd in the Morning by your Characters.—I would not have you dejected, you shall not want a Character.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This was the most unfortunate Accident sure, that ever befel a Woman of Virtue.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: If you are a Woman of Virtue, the Gentleman will be hanged for attempting to rob you of it. If you are not a Woman of Virtue, why you will be whipped for accusing a Gentleman of robbing you of what you had not to lose.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! this unfortunate Fright!—But, Mr. Constastable, I am very willing that the Gentleman should have his Liberty, give me but mine.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: That Request, Madam, is a very colloborating Circumstance against you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Guilt will ever discover it self.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Bring them along▪

sp.speaker: 1Watch.
sp.p: She looks like a modest Woman, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Confound all your modest Women, I say—a Man can have nothing to do with a modest Woman, but he must be married, or hanged for't.

div3.head: SCENE I.
SCENE Justice Squeezum's; a Table, Pen Ink, Paper, &c.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: DID Mother Bilkum refuse to pay my Demands, say you?

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; she says she does not value your Worship's Protection of a Farthing, for that she can bribe two Juries a Year to acquit her in Hicks's-Hall, for half the Money which she hath paid you within these three Months.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
Very fine! I shall shew her that I understand something of Juries, as well as her self. Quill, make a Memorandum against Mother Bilkum's Trial, that we
may remember to have the Pannel No 3. they are a Set of good Men and true, and hearken to no Evidence but mine.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Snap the Bailiff's Follower hath set up a Shop, and is a Freeholder. He hopes your Worship will put him into a Pannel on the first Vacancy.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Minute him down for No 2. I think half of that Pannel are Bailiffs Followers. Thank Heaven, the Laws have not excluded those Butchers—

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: No, Sir, the Law forbids Butchers to be Jurymen, but does not forbid Jurymen to be Butchers.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Quill, d'ee hear! look out for some new Recruits for the Pannel No 1. We shall have a swinging Vacancy there the next Sessions.—Truly, if we do not take some care to regulate the Juries in the Old-Baily, we shall have no Juries for Hicks's-Hall.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Very true, Sir. But that Pannel hath been more particularly unfortunate. I believe I remember it hanged, at least twice over.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, poor Fellows! We must all take our Chance, Quill. The Man who would live in this World, must not fear the next. The Chance of Peace is doubtful as that of War; and they who will make their Fortunes at Home, should entertain no more Dread of the Bench, than a Soldier should of the Field. We are all militant here, and a Halter hath been fatal to many a great Man, as well as a Bullet.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir, here's Mr. Staff, the Reforming Constable.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: An't please your Worship, we have been at the Gaming-House in the Alley, and have taken Six Prisoners, whereof we discharged two who had your Worship's License.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What are the others?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p:
One is an Half-pay Officer; another an Attorney's
Clerk; and the other two are young Gentlemen of the Temple.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Discharge the Officer and the Clerk, there is nothing to be got by the Army or the Law; the one hath no Money, and the other will part with none. But be not too forward to quit the Templers.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Asking your Worship's Pardon, I don't care to run my Finger into the Lion's Mouth. I would not willingly have to do with any Limb of the Law.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Fear not; these bear no nearer Affinity to Lawyers, than a Militia Regiment of Squires do to Soldiers; the one gets no more by his Gown, than the other by his Sword. These are Men that bring Estates to the Temple, instead of getting them there.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Nay, they are bedawb'd with Lace as fine as Lords.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Never fear a Lawyer in Lace—the Lawyer that sets out in Lace, always ends in Rags.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I'll secure them.—We went to the House where your Worship commanded us, and heard the Dice into the Street, but there were two Coaches with Coronets on them at the Door, so we thought it proper not to go in.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You did right. The Laws are Turnpikes, only made to stop People who walk on Foot, and not to interrupt those who drive through them in their Coaches.—The Laws are like a Game at Loo, where a Blaze of Court Cards is always secure, and the Knaves are the safest Cards in the Pack.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: We have taken up a Man for a Rape too.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I fancy he's some great Man; for he talks French, sings Italian, and swears English.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Is he rich?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I believe not, for we can't get a Farthing out of him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A certain Sign that he is. Deep Pockets are like deep Streams; and Money, like Water, never runs faster than in the Shallows.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Then there's another Misfortune too.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: The Woman will not swear any thing against him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Never fear that, I'll make her swear enough for my Purpose. What sort of a Woman is she?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: A common Whore, I believe.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: The properest Person in the World to swear a Rape. A modest Woman is as shy of swearing a Rape, as a Gentleman is of swearing a Battery.—We will make her swear enough to frighten him into a Composition, a small Part of which will satisfie the Woman. So go bring them before me.—But hold! have you been at home since I sent a Prisoner thither this Morning?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Yes, an't please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: And what says he?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: He threatens us confoundedly; and says you have committed him without any Accusation. I'm afraid we shall get nothing out of him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: We'll try him till Noon, however.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I desire, Mr. Squeezum, you would finish all your dirty Work this Morning, for I am resolved to have the House to my self in the Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You shall, my Dear; and I shall be obliged to you, if you can let me have the Coach this Morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I shall use it my self.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Then I must get Horses put into the Chariot.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I am not determined whether I shall use the Coach or Chariot, so it is impossible you should have either. Besides, a Hack is the properest to do Business in, and as I cannot spare you a Servant, will look better.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
Well, Child, well, it shall be so.—Let
me only beg the Favour of Dining a little sooner than ordinary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: That is so far from being possible, that we cannot Dine 'till an Hour later than usual, because I must attend at an Auction, or I shall lose a little China Basin which is worth its Weight in Jewels, and it is probable I may get it for its Weight in Gold, which will not be above One Hundred Guineas, and those you must give me, Child.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A Hundred Guineas for a China Bason! Oh the Devil take the East-India Trade! The Clay of the one Indies runs away with all the Gold of the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I may buy it for less; but it is good to have rather too much Money about one, than too little.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: In short, I cannot support your Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I do not desire you to support my Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I wish you would not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Thus stands the Case: You say I am extravagant; I say, I am not; sure, my Word will ballance yours every where but at Hicks's-Hall.—And heark'e, my Dear, if whenever I ask for a Trifle, you object my Extravagance to me, I'll be reveng'd, I'll blow you up, I'll discover all your midnight Intrigues, your protecting Ill Houses, your bribing Juries, your snacking Fees, your whole Train of Rogueries. If you do not allow me what I ask, I'll bid fair to enter on my Jointure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, my Dear, this Time you shall be indulged.—Trust a Thief or Lawyer with your Purse, a Whore or Physician with your Constitution, but never trust a dangerous Secret with your Wife; for when once you have put it into her Power to hang you, the sooner you are hang'd, the better.

div3.head: SCENE IV.
div3.stage: Squeezum, Quill, Mrs. Squeezum, Staff, Watch, Ramble, Hilaret.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: An't please your Worship, here is a Gentleman hath committed a Rape last Night on this young Woman.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: How! a Rape! Hath he committed a Rape on you, Child?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: This may be worth hearing.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I have nothing to say against him. I desire you would give us both our Liberty. He was a little frolicksome last Night, which made me call for these People's Help, and when once they had taken hold of us, they would not suffer us to go away.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: They did their Duty.—The Power of Discharging lieth in us, and not in them.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, I beg we may not be interrupted. Heark'e, young Woman, if this Gentleman hath treated you in an ill manner, do not let your Modesty prevent the Execution of Justice. Consider, you will be guilty your self of the next Offence he commits; and upon my Word, by his Looks, it is probable he may commit a Dozen Rapes within this Week.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I assure you he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Mr. Staff, what say you to this Affair?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: May it please your Worship, I saw the Prisoner behave in a very indecent manner, and heard the Woman say he had ravished away her Senses.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Fye upon you, Child, will you not swear this?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I shall swear something against you, unless you discharge us.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: That cannot be, Madam, the Fact is too plain. If you will not swear now, the Prisoner must be kept in Custody 'till you will.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: If she will not swear, we can swear enough to convict him.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Very fine, faith! this Justice is worse than a Grand Inquisitor. Pray, honest, formidable Sir, what private Pique have you against me, that you would compel the Lady to deserve the Pillory, in order to promote me higher?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: My Dear, did you ever see such a ravishing Look as this Fellow hath! Sir, if I was a Judge I would hang you without any Evidence at all. They are such Fellows as these who sow Dissention between Man and Wife, and keep up the Names of Cuckold and Bastard in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nay, if that be all you accuse me of, I will confess it freely, I have employ'd my Time pretty well: Tho' as I do not remember ever to have done you the Honour of Dubbing, Mr. Justice, I cannot see why you should be so incensed against me; for I do not imagine you any otherwise an Enemy to these Amusements, than a Popish Priest to Sin, or a Doctor to Disease.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You are very civil, Sir, to threaten to dub my Husband before my Face.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I ask Pardon, Madam; I did not know with whom I had the Honour to be in Company; it was always against my Inclination to affront a Lady; but a Woman of your particular Merit, must have claimed the most particular Respect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I should have expected no Rudeness from a Gentleman of your Appearance, and would much rather attribute any misbecoming Word to Inadvertency, than Design.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Madam, I know not how to thank so much Goodness; but do assure you, I would buy an Introduction to your Acquaintance at a much greater Danger than this Prosecution, which, I believe, you already see the Malice of. I hope, Madam, I stand already acquitted in your Opinion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, it will only appear to have been a Frolick: I must own I have been always a great Enemy to Force—since there are so many willing.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: So, I find there is no danger of a Rape here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Well, Child, can you find any thing against this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: The Woman is difficult of confessing in publick: but I fancy when I examine her in private I may get it out of her—So, Mr. Constable, withdraw your Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Nay he appears so much of a Gentleman, that till there be stronger Evidence, I will take Charge of him—Come, Sir, you shall go drink a dish of Tea with me—You may stay without.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This Kindness of yours, Madam, will be an Encouragement to Offenders.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Come, come, Child, you had better take the Oath, tho' you are not altogether so sure. Justice should be rigorous. It is better for the Publick that ten Innocent People should suffer, than that one Guilty should escape; and it becomes every good Person to sacrifice their Conscience to the Benefit of the Publick.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Would you persuade me to perjure my self?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: By no means. Not for the World. Perjury indeed! do you think I do not know what Perjury is, better than you? He did attempt to Ravish you, you own; very well. He that attempts to do you an Injury, hath done it in his Heart. Besides, a Woman may be Ravished, ay and many a Woman hath been Ravished, ay and Men been hanged for it—when she hath not certainly known she hath been Ravished.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You are a great Casuist in Conscience. But you may spare your self any further Trouble: for I assure you it will be in vain.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
I see where your Hesitation hangs, you are afraid of spoiling your Trade—You think Severity to a Customer, will keep People from your House.—
Pray answer me one Question—How long have you been upon the Town?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Come, come, I see you are but a Novice, and I like you the better: For yours is the only Business, wherein People do not profit by Experience—You are very handsome—It is Pity you should continue in this abandoned State—Give me a Kiss—Nay be not coy to me—I protest you are as full of Beauty as the Rose is of Sweetness, and I of Love as its Stalk is full Briars—Oh! that we were as closely joined together too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why you will commit a Rape your self, Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: If I thought you would prove constant, I would take you into keeping: for I have not liked a Woman so much these many Years.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I will humour this old Villain, I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What think you, could you be constant to a vigorous, healthy, middle-aged Man, hey!—could this buy thy Affections off from a set of idle Rascals, who carry their Gold upon their Backs; and have Pockets as empty as their Heads? Fellows who are greater Curses on a Woman than the Vapours; for as those persuade her into imaginary Diseases, these present her with real.—Let thy Silence give Consent; here take this Purse as an Earnest of what I'll do for you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, and what shall I do for this?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You shall do—You shall do nothing, I will do: I will be a Verb Active, and you shall be a Verb Passive.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wish you be not of the Neuter Gender.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Why you little arch Rogue, do you understand Latin, Hussy?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: A little, Sir! my Father was a Country Parson, and gave all his Children a good Education. He taught his Daughters to write and read himself.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What, have you Sisters then?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Alack-a-day, Sir! sixteen of us, and all in the same way of Business.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, this it is to teach Daughters to write. I would as soon put a Sword into the Hand of a Madman, as a Pen into those of a Woman; for a Pen in the Hand of a Woman is as sure an Instrument of Propagation, as a Sword in that of a Madman is of Destruction [Aside.] —Sure, my Dear, the Spirit of Love must run very strongly in the Blood of your whole Family.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! it was a villanous Man of War that harboured near us—My poor Sisters were ruined by the Officers, and I fell a Martyr to the Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the Sailors are as fatal to our Women as the Soldiers are. One Venus rose from the Sea, and thousands have set in it—But not Venus her self could compare to thee, my little Honey-suckle.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Be not so hot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Bid the Touchwood be cold behind the Burning-glass. The Touchwood is not more easily kindled by the Sun, than I by your dear Eyes.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The Touch wood is not drier, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: But hark, I hear my Wife returning—leave word with my Clerk where I shall send to you—I will be the kindest of Keepers, very constant, and very liberal.—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Two charming Qualities in a Lover!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: My pretty Nose-gay, you will find me vastly preferable to idle young Rakehells. Besides, you are safe with me. You are as safe with a Justice in England, as a Priest abroad; Gravity is the best Cloak for Sin, in all Countries—Be sure to be punctual to the Time I shall appoint you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Be not afraid of me.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Adieu, my pretty Charmer. I shall burn with Impatience.

Go thy ways for a charming Girl! Now if I can get her at this wild Fellow's Expence, I shall have performed the part of a shrewd Justice; for I would make others
pay for my Sins, as well as their own. I fancy my Wife hath sufficiently frightned him by this, and that he will truckle to any Terms to be acquitted; for I must own she will pump a Man much better than I—Oh! here they come; I must deal with my Gentleman now, in another Style.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, Sir, is the Lady determined to swear stoutly?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Truly, it is hard to say what she determines; she is gone to ask the Advice of a Divine and a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then the odds is against me: for the Lawyer will certainly advise her to swear, and it is possible the Priest may not contradict her in it.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: It is indeed a ticklish Point, and it were advisable to make it up as soon as possible. The first Loss is always the least. It is better to wet your Coat than your Skin, and to run home when the Clouds begin to drop, than in the middle of the Storm. In short, it were better to give a brace of hundred Pounds to to make up the Matter now, than to venture the Consequence. I am heartily concerned, to see a Gentleman in such a Misfortune. I am sorry the Age is so corrupt. Really I expect to see some grievous and heavy Judgment fall on the Nation. We are as bad as ever Sodom and Gomorrah were, and I wish we may not be as miserable.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Heark'e, Justice; I take a Sermon to be the first Punishment which a Man undergoes after conviction. It is very hard I must be condemned to it before-hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I am sure Mr. Squeezum speaks for your good.—I shall get a Necklace out of this Affair.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, that I am sure I do, my Interest sways not one way or the other—I would, were I in that Gentleman's Circumstances, do what I advise him to.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, that I must doubt: for were you in my Circumstances, you would not be worth the Money.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, now you jest with me; a Gentleman can never be at a loss for such a Trifle.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Faith! you mistake. I know a great many Gentlemen not worth three Farthings: he that resolves to be honest cannot resolve not to be poor.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A Gentleman, and poor! Sir, they are Contradictions. A Man may as well be a Scholar without Learning, as a Gentleman without Riches. But I have no time to dally with you. If you do not understand good Usage, while it is dealt you, you may, when you feel the Reverse. The Affair may now be made up for a Trifle; the time may come when your whole Fortune would be too little—An Hour's Delay in the making up an Offence is as dangerous as in the sewing up of a Wound.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, you have over-persuaded me, I'll take your Advice.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll engage you will not repent it—I don't question but you will regard me as your Friend.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That I do indeed. And to give you the most substantial Instance of it, I will ask a Favour, which is expected only from the most intimate Friendship—which is, that you would be so kind to lend me the Money.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Alack-a-day, Sir, I have not such a Sum in my Command. Besides, how must it look in me, who am an Officer of Justice, to lend a Culprit Money wherewith to evade Justice! Alas, Sir, we must consider our Characters in Life, we must act up to our Characters; and tho' I deviate a little from mine, in giving you Advice, it would be entirely forsaking the Character of a Justice to give you Money.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I wonder how you could ask it.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Necessity obliges to any thing, Madam. Mr. Squeezum was so kind to shew me the Necessity of giving Money, and my Pockets were so cruel to shew me the Impossibility of it.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well Sir, if you cannot pay for your Transgressions like the Rich, you must suffer for them like the Poor.—Here, Constable.

div3.head: SCENE VIII.
div3.stage: Squeezum, Mrs. Squeezum, Ramble, Staff, Constables.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Take away your Prisoner, keep him in safe Custody till farther Orders. If you come to a wiser Resolution within these two Hours, send me Word; after that it will be too late.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Heark'e, Mr. Justice, you had better use me as you ought, and acquit me; for if you do any thing which you cannot defend, hang me if I am not revenged on you.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Hang you!—I wish there may not be more Meaning in those Words than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! you old Rascal, I can scarce forbear rattling those old dry Bones of thine, till they crack thy withered Skin.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Bear Evidence of this, I am threatned in the Execution of my Office.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Come, honest Mr. Constable, Mr. nocturnal Justice, let me go any where from this Fellow—the Night hath chosen a better Justice than the Day.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I am afraid I shall make nothing of this Fellow at last. I have a Mind to discharge him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Oh! by no means; for I am sure he hath Money.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Yes, and so am I. But suppose he will not part with it; it is impossible to take it from him; for there is no Law yet in being to skreen a Justice of Peace from a downright Robbery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Try him a little longer, however.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
I will, 'till the Afternoon; but if he should not consent by that Time, I must discharge him, for
I have no Hopes in the Woman's Swearing. She is discharged already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I'll make him a Visit at the Constable's House, and try if I can alarm him into a Composition. I may make him do more than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do so, my Dear;—I doubt not your Power—Good-morrow, Honey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: But, my Dear, pray remember the Hundred Guineas.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I shall remember them; they are not likely to be soon forgotten.—Follow me to my Escritore.

Since you are sure of going to the Devil, honest Spouse, I'll take Care to equip you with a Pair of Horns, that you may be as like one another as possible. This dear wild Fellow must be mine, and shall be mine: I like him so well, that if he had even ravished me, on my Conscience I should have forgiven him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Mr. Politick, I am heartily sorry for this Occasion of renewing our Acquaintance. I can imagine the Tenderness of a Parent, tho' I never was one.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed, Neighbour Worthy, you cannot imagine half the Troubles, without having undergone them. Matrimony balks our Expectations every way, and our Children as seldom prove Comforts to us as our Wives. I had but two—whereof one was hanged long ago—and the other I suppose may be in a fair Way by this.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: In what manner did she escape from you?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: She had taken Leave of me to retire to Rest, not half an Hour before I heard of her Departure. I impute it all to the wicked Instructions of an Imp of the Devil called a Chamber-maid, who is the Companion of her Flight.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But do you know of no Lover?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Let me see—hey!—There hath been a Fellow in a Red Coat, with whom she hath conversed for some time, in spite of my Teeth.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Depend on it, He is the Occasion of your Loss. I can grant you a Warrant against him, if you know his Name, tho' I fear you are too late.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, Sir, I am not too late; my Daughter is an Heiress, and you know the Punishment for stealing an Heiress. If I could hang the Rascal, it would be some Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: That will be impossible, without her Consent; and truly, if she be married, I would advise you to follow the Example of that Emperor, who when he discovered something worse than a Marriage, between one of his Subjects and his Daughter, chose rather to let him enjoy her as his own, than punish him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray where did that Emperor reign?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I have almost forgotten, but I think it was one of the Greek Emperors, or one of the Turks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Bring me no Example from the Turks, good Mr. Worthy, I find no such Affinity in our Interests. Sir, I dread and abhor the Turks. I wish we do not feel them, before we are aware.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But Sir—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But me no buts—what can be the Reason of all this warlike Preparation, which all our Newspapers have informed us of. Yes, and the same Newspapers a hundred times in the same Words. Is the Design against Persia? Is the Design against Germany? Is the Design against Italy—Suppose we should see Turkish Gallies in the Channel? We may feel them, yes, we may feel them in the midst of our Security; Troy was taken in its Sleep, and so may we.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, you are asleep, or in a Dream—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, yes, these things are called idle Dreams—the justest Apprehensions may be styled Dreams—but let me tell you, Sir, Men betray their own Ignorance often, in attacking that of other Men.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But what is all this to your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Never tell me of my Daughter, my Country is dearer to me than a thousand Daughters; should the Turks come among us, what would become of our Daughters then? and our Sons, and our Wives, and our Estates, and our Houses, and our Religion, and our Liberty.—When a Turkish Aga should command our Nobility, and Janizaries make Grandfathers of Lords? Where should we look for Britain then?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Truly, where I may look for Mr. Politick now, in the Clouds.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Give me leave, Sir, only to let you a little into the present State of Turkey.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I must beg to be excused, Sir; if I can be of any Service to you, in relation to your Daughter, you may command my Attention: I may probably defend you from your own Countrymen, but truly from the Turks I cannot.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am glad to hear you have some Apprehension of them, as well as my self.—That you are not so stupidly besotted, as I meet with some People at the Coffee-house; but perhaps you are not enough apprized of the Danger. Give me leave only to shew you, how it is possible for the Grand Signior to find an Ingress into Europe.—Suppose, Sir, this Spot I stand on to be Turkey—then here is Hungary—Very well—here is France, and here is England—granted—then we will suppose he had Possession of Hungary—what then remains but to conquer France, before we find him at our own Coast.—But, Sir, this is not all the Danger; now I will shew you how he can come by Sea to us.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Dear Sir, refer that to some other time; you have sufficiently satisfied me, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is almost time to go to the Coffee-house—so dear Mr. Worthy, I am your most obedient Servant.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, your very humble Servant.

I recollect the Dawnings of this political Humour to have appeared when we were at the Bath together, but it hath risen finely in these ten Years. What an Enthusiasm must it have arrived to, when it could make him forget the Loss of his only Daughter! The greatest Part of Mankind labour under one Delirium or other: And Don Quixotte differed from the rest, not in Madness, but the Species of it. The Covetous, the Prodigal, the Superstitious, the Libertine, and the Coffee-house Politician, are all Quixottes in their several Ways.
sp.l: That Man alone from Madness free, we find,
Who, by no wild unruly Passion blind,
To Reason gives the Conduct of his Mind.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: DEAR Cloris.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Dear Madam, is it you? you altogether?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ay, ay, altogether, thank Heavens! I had like to have lost something, but all's safe I assure you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, I wish it were.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What, don't you believe me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I wish you could not me, or I my self. Poor Capt. Constant—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh! Madam!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Speak quickly, or kill me, which you please—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: —Is taken up for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: It is too true, his own Servant told me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: His Servant belied him, and so do you—shew me where he is, if he be in a Dungeon, I'll find him out.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Very generous indeed, Madam! A King should sooner visit a Prisoner for Treason, than I a Lover for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It would be unpardonable in me to entertain so flagrant a Belief at the first hearing, against a Man who hath given me such substantial Proofs of his Constancy: Besides, an Affair of my own makes me the more doubtful of the Truth of this; but if there appear any Proof of such a Fact I will drive him for ever from my Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, Justice Squeezum will take care to have him driven another Way.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Justice Squeezum! let me hug you for that Information. Now, I can almost swear he is Innocent: I have such an Adventure to surprize you with; but let me not lose a Moment—come, shew me the way.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Poor Creature! She knows the way to her Destruction too well—but it would be Impertinence in a Servant to put her out of it.

I begin to be of that Philosopher's Opinion, who said, that whoever will entirely consult his own Happiness, must be little concerned about the Happiness of others. Good-nature is Quixotism, and every Princess Micomicona will lead her Deliverer into a Cage. What had I to do to interpose! What harm did the Misfortunes of an unknown Woman bring me, that I should
hazard my own Happiness and Reputation on her Account?—But sure, to swear a Rape against me for having rescued her from a Ravisher, is an unparalelled Piece of Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Will your Honour please to drink a Dram, or some 'Rack Punch?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Dear Madam, do not trouble me; I can drink nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, but I can. Not trouble you! I had never such a Customer here before. You a Captain charged with a Rape!—I should sooner take you for some poor Attorney, charged with Forgery and Perjury: o a travelling Parson, with stealing a Gown and Cassock.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Drink what you will, and I'll pay what you please.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Thank your Honour! Your Honour will not be offended, I hope—we stand at a great Rent: and truly, since this Gin Act, Trade hath been so dull, that I have often wished my Husband would live by the Highway himself, instead of taking Highwaymen.

sp.speaker: Const
sp.p: You are not the only Wife who would give her Husband this Advice, I dare swear. Nay, were Men all so uxorious to take it, Tyburn would have as much Business as Doctors-Commons.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: I wish it had more; for we must stand and fall by one another; no business there, no Business here; and truly Captain, 'tis with Sorrow I say it, where we have one Felon now, we had ten, a Year or two ago—I have not seen one Prisoner brought in for a Rape this Fortnight, except your Honour. I hope your Handsel will be lucky.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Captain, your Servant, I suppose you will be glad of Company—here is a very civil Gentleman, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: More Gentlemen! This is rare News indeed.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I had rather be alone.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I have but this one Prison-Room, Captain: besides, I assure you, this is no common Fellow, but a very fine Gentleman, a Captain too—and as merry a one—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What is the Cause of his Misfortune?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: A Rape, Captain, a Rape—no dishonourable Offence—I would not have brought any Scoundrels into your Honour's Company: but Rape and Murder no Gentleman need be ashamed of; and this is an honest Brother-Ravisher—I have ravished Women my self formerly: but a Wife blunts a Man's Edge. When once you are married, you will leave off Ravishing, I warrant you—to be bound in Wedlock is as good a Security against Rapes, as to be bound over to the Peace is against Murther.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: My Husband will have his Jest. I hope your Honour will pardon him.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: But here is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Prodigious!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Dear Constant!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What in the Name of Wonder hath brought you to England?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What in the Devil's Name hath brought thee to the Constable's?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Only a Rape, Sir, no dishonourable Offence, as Mr. Constable hath it.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You jest.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: No, Sir, upon my Word the Captain is in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why I should sooner have suspected Ermin or Lawn-Sleeves. But I see Gravity and Hypocrisy are inseparable—Well, give me thy Hand, Brother, for our Fortunes agree exactly.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: And will agree in the End, I don't question. This is not the first time of their meeting together on this Account; a Couple of old Whore-masters, I warrant 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Will your Honours please to drink any Punch, noble Captains, it will keep up your Spirits.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Don't force the Gentlemen, Wife, to drink whether they will or no.—I wish you well off this Affair—in the mean time, whatever my House affords is at your Service—and let me assure you, the more you drink the less you will lament your Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Spoken like a true Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But, dear Billy, I hope thou hast not really committed, hey?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What I heartily repent of, I assure you. I rescued a Woman in the Street, for which she was so kind to swear a Rape against me; but it gives me no Uneasiness equal to the Pleasure I enjoy in seeing you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ever kind and good-natur'd!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yet I wish our Meeting had been on another Occasion, for the Freedom of your Life makes me suspect the Consequence of your Confinement may be heavier than mine.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I can't tell what the Consequence may be, nor shall I trouble my self about it: But I assure thee, no sucking Babe can be more innocent. If our Cases differ in any thing, it is in this, that my Woman hath not sworn.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
This pleases me indeed!—But pray, how
came you to leave the Indies, where I thought you had been settled for Life?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why on the same Account that I went thither, that I now am here, by which I live, and for which I live, a Woman.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, a fine, young, rich Woman! a Widow with Fourscore Thousand Pounds in her Pocket—there's a North Star to steer by.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What is her Name?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Her Name!—her Name is Ramble.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What, Married!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, Sir; soon after you left the Indies, honest Mr. Ingot left the World, and me the Heir to his Wife with all her Effects.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I wish you Joy, dear Jack; this thy good Fortune hath so filled me with Delight, that I have no Room for my own Sorrows.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But I have not unfolded half yet.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: [without.] Let two Quarts of Rum be made into Punch, let it be hot—hot as Hell.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: D'ye hear, we are in a fine Condition 'faith!

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Here they are, here are a Brace of desponding Whore-masters for you—Ramble, what nothing to say in Praise of the Women, Mark Anthony made a fine Bargain, hey, when he gave the World for a Woman? 'Sdeath! if he had been alive now I'd have waged Six Gallons of Claret, I had seen him hanged for a Rape—as I shall very suddenly my two worthy Friends.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hearkee, Sotmore, if you say any thing against the Women, we'll cut your Throat, and toss Justice in a Murder into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
Not speak against Women! you shall as soon compel me not to drink; you shall sow up my Lips,
if you do either—Here, you, let the Punch be gotten ready.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: It shall, an't please your Honour. (This Gentleman is a rare Customer to a House, I wish he would commit a Rape too.)

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You must not rail against the Ladies, Sotmore, before Ramble; for he is a married Man.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And what is better, my Wife is at the bottom of the Sea.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And what is worse, all her Effects are at the bottom of the Sea with her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Faith! Sotmore hath spoken Truth for once.—Notwithstanding my Pleasantry, the Lady and her Fortune are both gone together; she went to the other World Fourscore Thousand strong; and if there be any such thing there, I don't question but she is married again by this Time.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You would not take my Advice. I have cautioned thee never to trust any thing on the same Bottom with a Woman. I would not ensure a Ship that had a Woman on Board, for double the Price.—The Sins of one Woman are enough to draw down a Judgment on a Fleet.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Here's a Fellow, who, like a Prude, makes Sin a Handle to his Abuse.—Art thou not ashamed to mention Sin—who art a Cargo of Iniquity? why wilt thou fill thy venom'd Mouth with that of others, when thou hast such Stores of thy own?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What occasioned your separating?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A Storm, and my ill Stars. I left the Ship wherein she was to dine with the Captain of one of our Convoy, when a sudden violent Storm arising, I lost sight of her Ship, and from that Day have never seen or heard of her.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
Nor ever will—I heartily hope. Tho' as for the Innocent Chests, those I wish deliver'd out of the
Deep. But the Sea knows its own good: It will be sure to keep the Money, tho' possibly it may refund the Woman; for a Woman will swim like a Cork, and they are both of the same Value, nay the latter is the more valuable, as it preserves our Wine, which Women often spoil.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why, Sotmore, Wine is the Touchstone of all Merit with thee, as Gold is to a Stock-jobber, and thou would'st as soon sell thy Soul for a Bottle, as he for a Guinea.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Wine, Sir, is as apt a Comparison to every thing that is good, as Woman is to every thing that is bad.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Fie, Sotmore! this railing against the Ladies will make your Company as scandalous to Gentlemen, as railing at Religion would to a Parson.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Right, Constant! they are my Religion, I am the High-Priest of the Sex.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Women and Religion! Women and the Devil: he leaves his Votaries in the Lurch, and so do they.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I fancy, Ramble, this Friend of ours will turn Parson, one day or other—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: If he was not such a Sot, I should think it possible:

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Why faith! I am almost superstitious enough to fancy this a Judgment on thee for breaking thy Word.—Did I not tell thee, thou wert stroling off to some little dirty Whore? and you see the Truth of my Prophecy.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Thou art in the right: It was not only a Whore, but the most Impudent of all Whores—a modest Whore.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: A modest Whore! let her be married to an honest Attorney, by all means.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And sent together to People His Majesty's Plantations.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Modesty now-a-days as often covers Impudence, as it doth Ugliness. It is as uncertain a sign of Virtue as Quality is, or as fine Cloaths are of Quality.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yet to do her Right: the Persuasions of the Justice could not prevail with her to perjure herself.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Conscientious Strumpet! She hopes to pick your Pocket another time, which it were Charity to thee to wish she might: for if thou escapest this, she certainly will have an Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Pray, honest Nol, how didst thou find us out? for a Boy would as soon have sent for his Schoolmaster when he was caught in an Orchard, as I for thee on this Occasion.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Find you out! why the Town rings of you—there is not a Husband or Guardian in it, but what is ready to get drunk for Joy. If the Woman be not Gold-Proof, she will be bribed to swear against you. You are a Nusance, Sir! I don't believe he hath been in Town Six Days, and he hath had above sixteen Women.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And they are a nobler Pleasure than so many Gallons which thou hast swallowed in that time.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Sir, I pay my Vintner, and therefore do no Injury.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And, Sir, I do no Injury: and therefore have no Reason to pay.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Hey-day! is taking away a Man's Wife or Daughter no Injury?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Not when the Wife is weary of her Husband, and the Daughter longs for one.

sp.speaker: Constant.
sp.p: Art thou not ashamed, Sotmore, to throw a Man's Sins in his Face, while he is suffering for them?

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: That is the time, Sir; besides you see what an effect it hath on him: you might as well rail at a Knight of the Post in the Pillory.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Let him alone, the Punch will be here immediately, and then he'll have no Leisure to rail.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
Is it not enough to make a Man rail, to have parted with a Friend happy in the Night, and to find him the next Morning in so fair a Way to—Death and Damnation! Shew me the Whore, I'll be revenged on her and the whole Sex. If thou art
hanged for Ravishing her, I'll be hanged for Murdering her. Describe the little Mischief to me. Is she tall, short, black, brown, fair? In what Form hath the Devil disguised himself?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: In a very Beautiful one, I assure you: she hath the finest Shape that ever was beheld, genteel to a Miracle, then the brightest Eyes that ever glanced on a Lover, the prettiest little Mouth, and Lips as red as a Cherry: And for her Breasts, not Snow, Marble, Lillies, Alabaster, Ivory can come up to their Whiteness; but their little, pretty, firm, round Form, no Art can imitate, no Thought conceive—Oh! Sotmore, I could die ten thousand Millions of Times upon them.—

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You are only like to die once for them.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: All these Raptures about a common Whore, Ramble?

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Ay, every Woman he sees, they are all alike to him, modest, or immodest, high or low, from the Garret to the Cellar, St. James's to the Stews; find him but a Woman, and he'll make an Angel of her.—He hath the same Taste for Women, as a Child for Pictures, or a hungry Glutton for an Entertainment: every Piece is a Venus, and every Dish an Ortelan.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: To say the Truth of her, Sotmore must have allowed her handsome, and I must allow her to have been a damn'd, confounded, common—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ha! Conjured up, by Jupiter! Well, my little Enemy, do the Priest and the Lawyer consent—and will you swear—ha!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: [Not regarding Ramble, runs to Constant.] My Constant!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hey-day! what, are we both in for Ravishing the same Woman?—I see by her Fondness, he hath really Ravished her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O, Hilaret! this Kindness of yours sinks me the deeper; can you bear to think on one accused of such a Crime as I am?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Never to believe it can I bear.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How shall I repay this Goodness! Then by Heavens I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hey! the Devil!—Is this Constant's Mistress? Here will be fine Work, i'faith!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Is this the Lady that did you the Favour, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This the Lady! No—why this is a Woman of Virtue; tho' she hath a great Resemblance of the other, I must confess.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Then I suppose this is she whom Constant hath Toasted this half Year—his Honourable Mistress, with a Pox.—Rare Company for a Man who is in Prison for a Rape!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And was you in that Scuffle which parted me and my Maid in Leicester-Fields?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: It was there this unfortunate Accident happened, while I was going to the Place of our Appointment.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It had like to have occasioned another to me, which, that I escaped, I am to thank this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! your most obedient, humble Servant. Was it you, dear Madam?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ha! is it possible my Friend can have so far indebted me!—This is a Favour I can never return.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You over-rate it, upon my Soul you do; I am sufficiently repayed by this Embrace.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I can never repay thee.—Would'st thou have given me Worlds, it could not have equall'd the least Favour conferr'd on this Lady.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I should have conferred some Favours on her indeed, if she would have accepted them.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am glad it is to Mr. Constant's Friend I am obliged.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Yes, you are damnably obliged to him for his Character of you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My dear Hilaret, shall I beg to hear it all? I can have no Pleasure equal to finding new Obligations to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Since you desire it—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I fancy, Madam, your Fright at that time may have occasioned your forgetting some Circumstance; therefore since Capt. Constant desires it, I will tell him the Story.—I had just parted from this Gentleman, when I heard a young Lady's Voice crying out for help; (I think the Word Rape was mentioned, but that I cannot perfectly remember;) upon this, making directly to the Place whence the Noise proceeded, I found this Lady in the Arms of a very rude Fellow—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The most impudent Fellow, sure, that ever was born!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A very impudent Fellow, and yet a very cowardly one; for the Moment I came up, he quitted his Hold, and was gone out of Sight in the Twinkling of an Eye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My dear Ramble, what hast thou done for me!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No Obligation, dear Constant! I would have done the same for any Man breathing. But to proceed; the Watch came up, who would not be satisfied with what she then said, but convey'd us both to the Round-House, whence we were carried in the Morning before Justice Squeezum, and by him, notwithstanding this Lady's Protestations, your humble Servant was committed to that Place where he now finds himself with this good Company.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh, my Friend!—May Heaven send me an Opportunity of serving thee in the same Manner!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: May that be the only Prayer which it denies to Constant.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: The Punch is ready, Gentlemen, you may walk down; the Liberty of my House is at your Service.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: And that is Liberty enough, while thou hast Punch here. If thy House were a Sea of Punch, I would not prefer any House in Town to it.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Your Honour shall not want that.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: And I shall want nothing more.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Captain, a Word with you. [To Ramble.] There's Madam Squeezum below desires to speak with you alone.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Bring her up.—Sotmore, you must excuse me a few Moments, Constant and this Lady will entertain you.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Let the Moments be very few. I'll lay Five Gallons to One, this Fellow hath another Whore in his Eye.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: So; my Affair with my Friend's Mistress is happily over.—That I should not know a modest Woman! But there is so great an Affectation of Modesty in some Women of the Town, and so great an Affectation of Impudence in some Women of Fashion, that it is not impossible to mistake. Now for Mrs. Justice, her Business with me is not exceeding difficult to guess.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You will think I have a vast deal of Charity, Captain, who am not only the Solicitress of your Liberty at home to my Husband, but can carry my Good-nature so far as to visit you in your Confinement. I cannot say but I have a generous Pity for any one whom I imagine to be accused wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am obliged to you indeed, Madam, for that Supposal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You are for the Cause of it. Wherefore do you imagine I ventured my self alone with you this Morning?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: From your great Humanity, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mr. Squeez.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! it was to try whether you were really the Man you were reported to be; and I am certain I found you as inoffensive, quiet, civil, well-bred a Gentleman as any virtuous Woman could have wished. Your Behaviour was so modest, that I can never imagine it possible you should have been guilty of a Rape. No over-grown Alderman of Sixty, or taper Beau of Six and Twenty, could have been more innocent Company.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Whu!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Your then Carriage hath wrought so great an Effect upon me, that I have ventured to trust my self here with you; nay, I could trust my self any where with so modest a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I'll take care, Madam, never to forfeit your good Opinion of me; you may trust your self with me any where; I'll never behave in any other manner than becomes the best-bred Man alive with the best-bred Lady. I swear by this soft Hand, these Lips, and all the Millions of Charms that dwell in this dear Body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I know not what I mean; Tongue can't express, nor Thought conceive—we can only feel the exquisite Pleasures Love has in store.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Nay, I protest, and vow.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Protestations are as vain as Struggling. This Closet hath a Bed in it that would not disgrace a Palace.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: [At the Door.] Why, Ramble! Jack Ramble! Art thou not ashamed to leave thy Friends thus, for some little dirty Strumpet? If thou dost not come immediately, we'll break open the Door, and drown her in Punch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: [Softly.] I am undone!—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Fear nothing—Go to your Bowl, I'll come this Instant.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: I'll not wag without you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then I'll come down, break your Bowl and spill all your Liquor.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Bring thy Whore along with thee; there's one there already, she'll be glad of her Company: If you don't come in an Instant I will be back again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Angel! Love shall instruct thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Let me go—some other time—I will not run any Venture here.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I will not part with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You shall hear from me in half an Hour. You shall have your Liberty, and I'll appoint you where to meet me.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Shall I depend on you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You may.—Adieu.—Don't follow me: I can slip out a back Way.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Farewel, my Angel!

Confound this drunken Rascal! This is not the first Time he hath spoiled an Intrigue for me. But hold, as I am to have my Liberty before-hand, I don't think this half Hour's Delay at all unlucky. That Consideration may sufficiently compensate the staying of my Stomach. This Adventure of mine begins to put on a tolerable Aspect.
