An Intrigue with a rich Justice's Wife, is not to be slighted by a young Fellow of a desperate Fortune. I do not doubt but in a very short Time, when I am taken up for the next Rape, to bribe the Justice with his own Money.—Lend a Man your Gold, he may forget the Debt; venture your Life for him, he may forget the Obligation; but once engage his Wife, and you secure his Friendship. There is no Friend in all Extremity so sure as your
Cuckold—and the surest Hold you can take of a Man, as of a Bull, is by his Horns.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Ha! what's become of thy Wench? if thou hadst none, thy Absence was the more inexcusable.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O Ramble! this our better Genius hath invented the most notable Plot!—Such a Net is laid for the Justice! it will at once entangle him and disentangle us. Mr. Hoggshead here is to play his Part too.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am sorry we cannot do without him; for should there be any Claret in his way, he'd disappoint the whole Affair for one Bottle.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Not for the best Burgundy in France. This Lady hath won my Heart by one Bumper.—By all the Pleasures of Drinking, Madam, I like you more than your whole Sex put together. There is no Honesty in Man or Woman, that will not drink. Honesty is tried in Wine, as Gold is in the Fire. Madam, you have made a Conquest of me. I'll drink your Health as long as I can stand, and that's as long as a reasonable Woman can require.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am exceedingly proud of my Conquest over a Man of Mr. Sotmore's good Sense.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Upon my Word you may, you are the first Woman I believe he ever was civil to.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: It was because they none of them had your Merit; a Parcel of Tea-drinking Sluts.—If I had a Daughter that drank Tea, I would turn her out of Doors. The Reason that Men are honester than Women is, their Liquors are stronger. If the Sex were bred up to Brandy and Tobacco, if they all liked Drinking as well as you seem to do, Madam, I should turn a Lover.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why, Constant, such another Compliment would make thee jealous.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Upon my Word, he hath Reason already!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Madam, I like you; and if a Bottle of Burgundy were on one side, and you on the other, I do not know which I should chuse.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Thou would'st chuse the Bottle, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But I long to hear this Conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Then it must be below. I strictly forbid any Secrets to be told but at the Council-Table. The Rose is ever understood over the Drinking-Room, and a Glass is the surest Turnkey to the Lips.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That's contrary to the Opinion of Philosophers.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p:
Of the sober ones it may; but all your wise Philosophers were a Set of the most drunken Dogs alive. I never knew a sober Fellow but was an Ass—and your Ass is the soberest of all Animals. Your sober Philosophers, and their Works, have been buried long ago. I remember a Saying of that great Philosopher and Poet, Horace, who wrote in Falernian instead of Ink:
No Verses last—can long escape the Night,
Which the dull scribling Water-drinkers write.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: YOU delivered my Letter?

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Yes, an't please your Worship, I left it at the Coffee-House, where she directed me.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Very well.—Quill!

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
I think I may trust thee with any Secret—and what I am now going to tell, will shew thee what
a Confidence I put in thee.—In short, Quill, I suspect my Wife—

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Of what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I am afraid that I am not the only Person free with her, and that I am free of the Corporation of Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Then your Worship is free of all the Corporations in England.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Now thou knowest that there are very wholesome Laws against Cuckoldom; the Advantage of a Man's Horns is, that he may shove his Wife out of Doors with them.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: And that is no inconsiderable Advantage.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: But there must be a Discovery first. It is not enough that a Man knows himself to be a Cuckold, the World must know it too. He that will keep his Horns in his Pocket, must keep his Wife in his Bosom. Therefore, Quill, as it is in your Power to observe my Wife, I assure you a very handsome Reward on her Conviction; for I begin to find, that if I do not discover her, she will shortly discover me, or ruin me by bribing her to hold her Tongue. It is not a little Gold will make a Gag for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be as diligent as possible.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: And I as liberal on your Success.

Indeed, Justice, that Bait will not do. I know you too well to trust to your Liberality. Your Wife will reward Services better than you. Besides, I have too much Honour to take Fees on both Sides.—And since I am her Pimp in ordinary, I'll go like an honest and dutiful Servant, and discover this Conspiracy; for should she once be turn'd out of the Family, I should make but a slender Market of this closefinger'd Justice, whose Covetousness would suffer no Rogues to live but himself.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This little Mistress of yours is the most dextrous Politician, if that drunken Puppy doth not disappoint us.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Never fear him! he hath Cunning enough, and there hath been so long a War in his Head between Wine and his Senses, that they seem now to have come to an Agreement that he is never to be quite in them, nor ever quite out of them; his Life is one continued Scene of being half Drunk.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, as we can be of no farther Use in the Affair, but must stay here and expect the Issue; pr'ythee tell me what hath become of you these three long long Years since you quitted the Service of the East-India Company, and came over to England with Sotmore?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why, at my first Return to England, the Prospect of War was in every one's Eye, and not only the Reports of the People, but the Augmentation of the Troops assured us of its Approach; upon which, I resolved to embarque my small Remains of Fortune in the Service of my Country, and obtained the same Commission on that Occasion, which I had enjoyed in the Indies. My History is not very full of Adventures; I continued therein 'till the Reduction, when I shared the Fate of several unhappy brave Fellows, and was sent a begging with a red Coat on my Back.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: It is the Faculty of the Cloth to be ragged.—Red is as apt to be ragged, as White to be soil'd. It is commonly the Fate of our brave Soldiers to bring home ragged Cloaths, as well as Colours, and both are rewarded by Westminster-Hall—the one is hung up in it, and the other is locked up safe by an Order from it; for, Heaven be prais'd! the Goals are always open Hospitals for us.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: The only Happiness which hath attended me since my Return, is my having contracted an Intimacy with that young Lady whom you saw here; which hath proceeded so far, that last Night we had appointed to meet in order to our Marriage; but as I was just arrived at the Place, a Woman well-dress'd was attacked in the Street by a Russian; I immediately flying to her Assistance, the Fellow quitted her, and left me alone in the Possession of the Watch, who early this Morning carried me before Justice Squeezum, and by him I was committed hither.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What, did she appear against you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No; they said she was ill of some Bruises she had received, but desired I might be kept in Custody 'till the Afternoon, at which Time she would appear against me. But by what Hilaret hath told us, and by some Methods which have been used to extort Money from me, I am inclined to fancy it all a contrived Piece of Villany of the Justice, and not of the Woman's, as I at first imagined.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Be assured of it;—if there be Roguery, the Justice hath the chief Part in it. But, comfort your self with the Expectation of Revenge, for I think he cannot possibly escape the Net we have spread, unless the Devil have more Gratitude than he is reported to have, and will assist his very good Friend at a Crisis.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But, what do you intend in England, where you have no Friends?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I know not yet whether I have or no. I left an old Father here, and a rich one. He thought fit to turn me out of Doors for some Frolicks, which it is probable, if he yet lives, he may have forgiven me by this. But what's become of him I know not, for I have not heard one Word of him these Ten Years.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I think you have been vastly careless, in neglecting him so long.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
'Tis as I have acted in all Affairs of Life; my Thoughts have ever succeeded my Actions; the
Consequence hath caused me to reflect when it was too late. I never reasoned on what I should do, but what I had done; as if my Reason had her Eyes behind, and could only see backwards.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Here is a Letter for your Honour.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: [Reads it.] Ay, this is a Letter indeed!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Freedom, under a Sign manual from the Queen of these Regions.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then, Sir, in plain English, without either Trope or Figure, it is a Letter from the Justice's Wife, with an Order to the Constable for my Liberty.

SIR,
I Was no sooner recovered of the Fright which that unmannerly Friend of yours occasioned, than I have performed my Promise; you will find me at Home; the Constable hath Orders by the Bearer to acquit you.
Here's Good-nature for you! [Kisses the Letter.] Thou dear Wife of a damn'd Rogue of a Justice, I fly to thy Arms.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Heark'e! suppose you brought her to be a Witness to our Design—and—here, take this Letter of Assignation from the Justice to Hilaret; it will give your Discovery Credit.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: An admirable Thought! I fly to execute it. Dear Constant, good-morrow. I hope when next we meet, we shall meet
sp.l: In happier Climes, and on a safer Shore,
Where no vile Justice shall invade us more.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Success attend you.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: No Woman been to enquire for Mr. Jones?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, I know of none, but I'll ask at the Bar if you please.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do—and leave Word if any such comes, to shew her up hither.—I have no Reason to doubt her Company, but I am impatient for it. I protest this Woman hath revived the Vigour of Youth in me; sure, I must have over-reckoned my Years!—I cannot be above Forty-Nine at the most.—I wish this dear Girl was come.—I am afraid I did wrong in giving her those Five Shillings, in a Purse worth above Two Shillings more, which who knows but she may be spending on some Bully, who will perhaps send another Present to me in return?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh! are you come—you little, pretty, dear, sweet Rogue!—I have been waiting for you these—these four Hours at least.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Young Lovers are commonly earlier than their Appointment.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Give me a Kiss for that.—Thou shalt find me a young Lover, a vigorous young Lover too.—Hit me a Slap in the Face, do.—Bow-wow! Bow-wow! I'll eat up your Cloaths.—Come, what will you drink? White or Red?—Women love White best.—Boy, bring half a Pint of Mountain.—Come, sit down; do, sit down.—Come, now let us hear the Story how you were first debauched.—Come—that I may put it down in my History at Home. I have the History of all the Women's Ruin that ever I lay with, and I call it, The History of my own Times.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I'll warrant it is as big as a Church-Bible.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: It is really of a good reputable Size: I have done Execution in my Time.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And may do Execution still.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: [Without.] Half a Pint of Mountain in the Lion, score.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well—But now let me have the History—Where did your Amour begin—at Church, I warrant you: more Amours begin at Church than end there.—Or perhaps, you went to see the Man of War—Going to see Sights hath ruined many a Woman. No wonder Children are Lovers of them, since so many owe their Being to them.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: [Aside.] I thank you for that remembrance, I had forgot my Lover.—Ay, Sir, it was there indeed I saw him first, that was the fatal Scene of our Interview.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, and was the Amour managed by Letter, or by word of Mouth?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: By Letter, Sir. I believe he writ two Quires of Paper to me before I would send him an Answer, I returned him several un-opened, and then several others opened—But at last—he obtained an Answer.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, and after your Answer, what followed then?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! he thought himself sure of me, as soon as I had answered his Letter.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, I have always observed in my Amours, that when I received an Answer, I never failed of the Woman; a Woman follows her Letter infallibly: well, and what did he say in the second Letter?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! he swore a thousand fond things, that his Love should last as long as his Life. That his whole Happiness depended on me—and a vast deal of that Nature.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, ay, just as I have done my self. I find Whoring is as Methodical as the Law.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And I fancy as tedious with you, old Gentle man.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, and how many Letters did you write to him, ey!—before—?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Not many. He did not want much Encouragement.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Then passing over the rest of the Suit, let us come to the last fatal Meeting.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It was of a Sunday Morning.—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Right. My old method: When other People are gone to Church.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: In an exceeding hot Day.—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: May or June?—Women and Cherries are commonly gathered in the same Month.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I was fatigued with walking in the Garden, and retired to an Arbour to repose my self: guess what was my Surprize, when I found the dear Perfidious had convey'd himself thither before me.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A sly Dog! My old way again. An Ambush is as useful in Love as War.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: At my first Entrance, he pretended a Surprize at seeing me unexpectedly: but on my questioning him how and with what Design he had conveyed himself there, he immediately threw off the Cloak and confessed all: he flew to me, caught me in his Arms with the most eager Raptures, and swore the most violent Love and eternal Constancy. I in the greatest Agony of Rage repelled him with my utmost Force; he redoubled his Attacks, I slackened my Resistance; he entreated, I raved; he sighed, I cry'd; he pressed, I swooned; he—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh!—I can bear no longer, my Angel! my Paradise! my Honey-suckle! my Dove! my Darling!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I mean to eat you up, to swallow you down, to squeeze you to Pieces.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Help there! a Rape, a Rape!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Hey-day! what in the Devil's name is here?—Justice Squeezum ravishing a Woman!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! for Heaven's sake, Sir, assist a poor forlorn, hapless Maid, whom this wicked Man hath treacherously seduced.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh lud!—Oh lud!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Fie upon you, Mr. Squeezum! you who are a Magistrate, you who are the Preserver and Executor of our Laws, thus to be the Breaker of them!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Can'st thou accuse me?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You know too well how barbarously you have used me. For Pity's sake, Sir, secure him; do not let him escape, 'till we send for a Constable. If there be any Law for a Justice, I am resolved to hang him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh lud! what Shame have I brought my self to! that ever I should live to see this Day!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: If thou hadst stood to thy Bottle like an honest Fellow this had never happened, but you must go a Whoring with a Pox to you, at your Years too; with these spindle Shanks, that weezle Face, that Crane's Neck of a Body. Who would have imagined that such an old withered May-pole as thou art should attempt to fall on a Woman? Why, thou wilt be the Diversion of the whole Town.—Grubstreet will dine a Month on your Account. Thou wilt be ushered to Tyburn with more Pomp then Alexander was ushered into Babylon. Justice never triumphs so universally as at the Execution of one of her own Officers.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, if there be Truth on Earth, I am as innocent—

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: All the Innocence on Earth will not save you—A Man doth not always draw the Rope by the weight of his Sins. Your Innocence will not acquit you in a Court of Justice, against her Oath; and when you come to the Gallows, it will be vain to plead your Innocence. All's Fish that comes to the Net there. The Gallows so seldom gets its due, that it never parts with what it gets.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Can you pretend to Innocence? was not this Gentleman an Eye-witness to your Rudeness, to the Injuries you offered me?

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I can swear to the Rape with as safe a Conscience as I can drink a Glass of Wine.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I see I am betrayed, I am caught in my own Trap. There is but one way to escape, which is the way I have opened to others. [Aside.] I see, Madam, your Design is to extort Money from me. I am too well acquainted with the Laws to contend: but I hope you will be reasonable, for I am poor, very poor, I assure you: it is not for Men of my Honesty to be rich.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, if you would give me Millions, it should not satisfie my Revenge; you shall be hanged for an Example to others.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Here's a cruel Wretch! who prefers my Blood to my Gold, which is almost my Blood.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Hey-day! what Vehicle is this? a Vinegar Bottle?—half a Pint, by Jupiter! Why, thou sneaking Rascal, can'st thou pretend to Honesty, when this Dram Glass hath been found upon thee? Were I thy Judge, or thy Jury, this very sneaking Vehicle should hang thee, without any other Evidence. But come, since you are to be hanged, I'll drink one Bumper to your good Journey to the other World—You will find abundance of your Acquaintance, whom you have sent before you—And now, I'll go call the Drawer to fetch a Constable.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir; for Mercy sake do not expose me so—Will nothing content you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nothing but the Rigour of the Law. Sir, I beseech you lose no Time, but send for the Constable immediately.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll do any thing, I'll consent to any Terms.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The Constable! the Constable!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Stay, dear Sir! I'll give you a hundred Guineas, I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Remember your vile Commitment of two Gentlemen this Morning—But I will revenge the Injuries of my Friends—Sir, I beseech you send for the Officers.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: One is already dismissed from his Confinement, and the other shall be dismissed immediately.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It is too late.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Hearkee, Sir, will you leave off Whoring, and take to Drinking for the future?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll leave them off both.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Then you shall be hanged: but if you will commence honest Fellow, and get drunk every Day of your Life, I'll intercede with this Lady, that on your acquitting the Gentleman you shall be acquitted your self.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll do any thing, I'll quit any thing.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Madam, let me persuade you to be merciful this time to this unfortunate and undutiful Servant of Justice.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Get me a Pen and Ink, I'll send an Order to bring him hither, and discharge him instantly.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Drawer, bring Pen, Ink and Paper, and a Bottle of old Port.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: [to Hil.] And could you have had the Conscience to have sworn against a poor old Man?

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Faith! 'twas a little cruel. Could you have had the Heart to see him swinging like a gibbeted Skeleton? could you have served up such a dry Dish to Justice—The Body of one of her own Children too?—But here's the Paper—Come, Sir, write his Discharge and your own.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You have managed this Matter so well, that I shall have an Opinion of your Sex's Understanding ever after.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let a Woman alone for a Plot, Mr. Sotmore.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, a Woman that will drink a Bumper. Wine is the Fountain of Thought, and
It is a Question with me, whether Wine hath done more Good, or Physick Harm in the World; I would have every Apothecary's Shop in the Town turn'd into a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am afraid the more you have of the one, the more you will require of the other.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: It is their Drugs that debauch our Wine: Wine in it self is as innocent as Water, and Physick poisons both. It is not the Juice of the Grape, but of the Drug, that is pernicious. Let me advise you, Madam, leave off your damn'd adulterated Water, your Tea, and take to Wine. It will paint your Face better than Vermilion, and put more Honesty in your Heart than all the Sermons you can read. I'll introduce you to some Clubs of my Acquaintance, a set of honest Fellows that live in the Clouds of Tobacco, and know no Home but a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: This Letter, Sir, will produce the Gentleman immediately.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Here, Drawer—let this Letter be sent whither it is directed. Come honest Justice, our Acquaintance hath an odd Beginning, but we may be very good Companions soon: Let us sit down and expect our Friend in the Manner it becometh us. Remember what you have bargained to do every Day of your Life, and the Obligation shall be dated from this Hour. Come, sit thee down, honest Publican, old Justice Merchant. [They sit] Here's a Health to the Propagation of Trade, thy Trade I mean, to the Encrease of Whores, and false Dice—Thou art a Collector of the Customs of Sin, and he that would sin with Impunity, must have thy Permit. Come, pledge me, old Boy; if thou leavest one Drop in the Glass, thou shalt go to Goal yet, by this Bottle.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I protest, Sir, your Hand is too bountiful, you will overcome me with Wine.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Well, and I love to see a Magistrate drunk; it is a comely Sight: When Justice is drunk, she cannot take a Bribe.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do you not remember how the Athenians punished Drunkenness in a Magistrate?

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
And do not I know that we have no such Athenian Law among us? We punish Drunkenness as well as other Sins, only in the Lower Sort: Drink,
like the Game, was intended for Gentlemen—and no one should get drunk, who cannot go home in a Coach—Come, Madam, it is your Glass now.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Dear Sir! I beg you would not compel me to it.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: By this Bottle, but I will, I'll ravish thee to it before the Justice's Face. Come, it will be better for you than Tea, you will not be obliged to sculk away and take a Dram after this. Come drink the Justice's Health, as a Token of Amity; the Justice is a good honest drunken Fellow. But let me give you some wholesome Advice, [to the Justice] leave off fornicating, leave the Girls to the Boys, and stand to thy Bottle: It is a Virtue becoming our Years; and don't be too hard on a wild honest young Rake. Thou hast committed a couple of the pretiest Boys to-day, don't do so any more.—Be as severe as you please to Whores and Gamesters, that offer to act without your License; but if ever you grant a Warrant for a Friend of mine again, you shall not only drink the Wine, but eat the Bottle too. Come, here's your Health, in Hopes of your Amendment; thou shalt pledge thy own Health in a Bumper—Here, Boy, bring up a Gallon of Wine.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Not a Drop more.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: A Drop! confound the Name. Come, empty your Glass; the Lady is a-dry.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: This is worse than a Prison.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You will get out of this with paying less Fees. Drink, I say.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well—since I must.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Come, we'll have a Song in praise of Drinking—I'll sing the Stanza's, and you shall bear the Chorus.

lg.l: Let a Set of sober Asses
Rail against the Joys of drinking,
While Water, Tea,
And Milk agree,
To set cold Brains a thinking:
Power and Wealth,
Beauty, Health,
Wit and Mirth in Wine are crown'd;
Joys abound,
Pleasure's found,
Only where the Glass goes round.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The Ancient Sects on Happiness
All differ'd in Opinion,
But wiser Rules,
Of Modern Schools,
In Wine fix her Dominion:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Wine gives the Lover Vigour,
It makes glow the Cheeks of Beauty,
Makes Poets write,
And Soldiers fight,
And Friendship do its Duty:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Wine was the only Helicon,
Whence Poets are long-liv'd so;
'Twas no other Main,
Than brisk Champaigne,
Whence Venus was deriv'd too:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: When Heav'n in Pandora's Box
All kind of Ill had sent us,
In a merry Mood,
A Bottle of Good
Was cork'd up, to content us:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: All Virtues Wine is Nurse to,
Of ev'ry Vice Destroyer;
Gives Dullards Wit,
Makes just the Cit,
Truth forces from the Lawyer:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Wine sets our Joys a flowing,
Our Care and Sorrow drowning.
Who rails at the Bowl,
Is a Turk in's Soul,
And a Christian ne'er should own him:
Power and Wealth, &c.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My Hilaret! my Dear!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Constant!

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Give you Joy, dear Constant, of your Liberty.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Thank you, dear Sotmore, to you I am partly obliged for it: Ramble and I will make you Amends▪ we'll give you six Nights for this.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Very safe; be not concerned about him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since our Affair is ended, there is the Purse you presented me this Morning. As I have not performed your Expectations one Way, I'll give you what I believe you did not expect—your Money again. It is unopen'd, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Thou art welcome however.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, be pleased to take every Man his Chair and his Glass; we will dedicate one Hour or two to drinking, I am resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: First we will sacrifice to Justice. Mr. Constable, do your Duty.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Come in there.

div3.head: SCENE IX.
div3.stage: Squeezum, Hilaret, Sotmore, Constant, Staff, Assistants.
The Assistants seize Constant, Hilaret, and Sotmore.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Seize those People in the King's Name—accuse that Woman and that Man of conspiring to wear a Rape against me.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: It is in vain to contend, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh the Villain!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: [to Sot.] The next Letter you extort, Sir, be sure to examine the Contents.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Thou Rascal! will not even Wine make thee Honest.

sp.speaker: Squeez
sp.p: Observe, Gentlemen, how abusive he is; but I'll make an Example of you all: I'll prosecute you to the utmost Severity of the Law,—Mr. Constable, convey the Prisoners to your House, whence you shall have Orders to bring them before a Justice.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And art thou really in Earnest?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You shall find I am, Sir, to your Cost.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Then I have found one Man with whom I would not drink a Glass of Wine.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, you know the Way to my House—I am particularly glad to see your Honour [to Sotmore] and will accommodate you in the best Manner I can.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am too well acquainted with Misfortune, to repine at any; but how shall I bear yours, my Hilaret?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The less you seem to bear, the more you will lighten mine.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: I must give the Justice one Wish. May Heaven rain Small-Beer upon thee, and may it corrupt thy Body, till it is as putrified as thy Mind.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: One Blessing only may Heav'n leave thy Life,
May it take all things from thee—but thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: SURE, never Child inherited less of a Father's Disposition than mine; her Mother certainly played me foul in the begetting her: I, who have been my whole Life noted for Sobriety, could never have given Being to so wild a Creature: I begin to recollect having seen a tall Half-pay Officer at my House formerly: Nor do I think the Girl unlike him. I am sure she hath been ever wild enough, to have had any Officer in the Kingdom for her Father. Nature hath been kind to the Male of all Creatures but Man: The Bull, the Horse, the Dog are not encumbered even with their own Off-spring; that Care falls only to the Females: But Man, when once a gabling Priest hath chattered a few mischievous Words over him, is bound to have and to hold from that Day forward all the Brats his Wife is pleased to bestow on him. Yet I must own the Girl hath been ever dutiful to me, till she became acquainted with this cursed Fellow in a Red Coat. Why should Red have such Charms in the Eyes of a Woman? The Roman Senate kept their Armies abroad to prevent their sharing in their Lands at home, we should do the same to prevent their sharing in our Wives. A tall lusty Fellow shall make more work for a Midwife in one Winter at home, than he can for a Surgeon in ten Summers abroad.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, any News of my Daughter yet?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No, Sir; but there is some News from the Secretaries Office, a Mail is arrived from Holland, and you will have the Contents of it in one of the Evening Papers.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Very well! I must be patient. I think we have three Mails together now: I am not satisfied at all with the Affairs in the North: The Northern Winds have not blown us any Good lately; the Clouds are a little darker in the East too than I could wish them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Mr. Dabble, good Morrow.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Are the Mails come in?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Just arrived.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I have not slept one wink for reflecting on what you told me last Night; perhaps this Dutch Mail may give some Insight into those Affairs. But what says the Lying-Post?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I have had no time to read it yet, I wish you would. I have only read, The London Journal, the Country Journal, the Weekly Journal, Applebee's Journal, the British Journal, the British Gazeteer, the Morning Post, the Coffee-House Morning Post, the Daily Post, the Daily Post-Boy, the Daily Journal, the Daily Courant, the Gazette, the Evening Post, the Whitehall Evening Post, the London Evening Post, and the St. James's Evening Post. So, if you please begin the Lying Post.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: [reads.] Moscow, January the fifth. 'We learn from Constantinople, that Affairs continue still in the same doubtful way, it is not yet known what Course our Court will take. The Empress having been slightly indisposed the other Day took the Air in her own Coach, and returned so well recovered, that she eat a very hearty Supper.'—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum—there is no mention of the Supper in any other Papers.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Berlin, January the 20th. 'We hear daily Murmurs here concerning certain Measures taken by a certain Northern Potentate; but cannot certainly learn either who that Potentate is, or what are the Measures which he hath taken—mean time we are well assured that Time will bring them all to light.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray read that last over again.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'Mean time, we are well assured that Time will bring them all to light.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum! hum!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Marseilles, January the 18th. 'The Affairs in regard to Italy, continue still in the same uncertain Condition.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'The Talk of a large Embarkation still runs high.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'The Spaniards continue still encamped near Barcelona.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum! [Shakes his Head.]

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'And every thing seems tending to a Rupture—mean time we expect the Return of a Courier from Vienna, who 'tis generally expected will bring the News of a general Pacification.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: All is well again!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I like this, and some other Papers, who disappoint you with good News. Where the beginning of a Paragraph threatens you with War, and the latter part of it ensures you Peace.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Please to read on—

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'However, notwithstanding these Assurances, 'tis doubted by most People, whether the said Courier will not rather bring a Confirmation of the War; but this is all guess-work, and till such time as we see an actual Hostility committed, we must leave our Readers in the same uncertain State we found them.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum! There is no Certainty to be come at, I find; it may be either Peace or War.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Tho' were I to lay a Wager, I should chuse War; for, if you observe, we are twice assured of that, whereas we have only one Affirmation on the side of Peace—but stay, perhaps the next Paragraph which is dated from Fontain-bleau may decide the Question. 'Fontain-bleau, January 23, Yesterday his Majesty went a Hunting, to-day he hears an Opera, and tomorrow he hears Mass.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I don't like that; hearing Mass is seldom the Forerunner of good News.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: ' It is observable that Cardinal Fleury'—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, now for it.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'It is observable that Cardinal Fleury hath for several Days last past been in close Conference with the Minister of a certain State, which causes various Speculations; but as we do not know what was the Matter in Debate, we cannot say what may be the Consequence thereof. Mean time we cannot help observing, that it hath occasioned some People to put on very serene Looks, who had worn cloudy ones for some time before: Some imagine on comparing this with the News from Marseilles, that a War will be unavoidable—others, who are more peaceably inclined, are as strenuous Advocates on the other side—We must refer the whole to the Determination of Time, that great Judge in worldly Affairs, who never fails with his two-edged Scithe to mow down the Weeds, which shadow over the secret Counsels of State, and lay them open to the naked Eye of the discerning Politician.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Shall I beg to hear that over again?

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: [reads.] 'We must refer the whole to the Determination,' &c.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! Cloris hath brought the strangest News of my young Mistress.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don't interrupt us—Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If you lose a Moment she may be lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sirrah! Peace.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, my young Mistress, Miss Hilaret, will be undone, ruined, hanged, if you do not assist her; she's taken up for a Rape—Oh! my poor young Lady! the sweetest, best-temper'd Lady sure that ever was born. Oh! that ever I should see the Day! And can you sit here, Sir, reading a parcel of damn'd confounded lying Nonsense, and not go to your Daughter's Assistance?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sure the Fellow is possessed.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, your Daughter is possessed—possessed by Constables—she is taken up for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My Daughter taken up for a Rape!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, for Ravishing a Justice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sure some Accident hath touched the Fellow's Brain.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and it would touch yours too, if you had a Grain of Humanity in you.—Oh! that I should live to see my poor young Lady in such a Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: A Woman taken up for a Rape—it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: They may swear it tho' for all that—I know her to be as modest a good young Lady as any in the Kingdom; but what will not a set of Rogues swear. Sir, I liv'd with Squeezum before I liv'd with you; and know him to be as great a Villain as any in the Kingdom. Do, good Sir, come but with me to Justice Worthy's, if you do not find your Daughter there, turn me away for a Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I do remember, Neighbour Politick, to have seen in some News-Paper a Story not very different from this.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, if you have seen it in a News-Paper, it may probably have some Truth in it; so Neighbour Dabble you will excuse me, I will meet you within an Hour at the Coffee-house, and there we will confer farther.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sure Modesty is quite banished from the Age we live in. There was a time when Virtue carried something of a divine Awe with it, which no one durst attack; but now the Insolence of our Youth is such, no Woman dare walk the Streets but those who do it for Bread.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And yet our Laws, Brother Worthy, are as rigorous as those of other Countries, and as well executed.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: That I wish they were; but Golden Sands too often clog the Wheels of Justice, and obstruct her Course: The very Riches which were the greatest Evidence of his Villany, have too often declared the Guilty innocent; and Gold hath been found to cut a Halter surer than the sharpest Steel.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Well, I am resolved to take care how I venture a step again after it is dark: I find the Sun is the only Guard to us Women; for however chaste the Moon may be in her self, she takes but very little care of ours.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But could the Villain be very rude?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: As rude as so short a time would permit. I would have given all I was worth in the World, to have been here; but since I escaped, let us forget it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Forget! By Heaven it shocks me, that we who boast as wholsome Laws as any Kingdom upon Earth, should by the Roguery of some of their Executors lose all their Benefit. I long to see the time when here, as in Holland, the Traveller may walk unmolested, and carry his Riches openly with him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Mr. Worthy, your humble Servant. I come to wait on you on the strangest Piece of Business. We are brought to a fine Pass indeed, when Magistrates shall not be safe; we are like to protect others, when we cannot protect our selves.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What is the occasion of all this Passion, Mr. Squeezum?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Occasion! I have scarce Power to tell you. I have discovered one of the most damnable Conspiracies, that hath been invented since the Gunpowder-Treason Plot.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Nothing against the Government, I hope.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Marry, but it is; for that which is against the Officers of the Government, is against the Government. In short, Sir, it is a Conspiracy against me, against my self. What do you think, Brother Worthy, but that moved and seduced by the Instigation of the Devil, a vile Woman hath conspired to swear a Rape against me?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: A Rape against you! foolish Jade! Why your very Face would acquit you—you have Innocence in your Looks, Brother Squeezum.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I hope my Character will acquit me against such an Accusation.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I think it ought; a Man whose Character would not, is very unfit for that honourable Commission you bear.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: True! these Slurs reflect on us all. The accusing a Member, is accusing the Body. We should consider it may be our own case. We should stand by one another, as the Lawyers do. I hope, Brother, you will shew me extraordinary Justice; and I assure you, should any Affair of yours come before me, my Partiality shall lean on your side.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Partiality, Sir! I hope no Cause of mine will ever require it. I assure you, I shall do you the strictest Justice; I believe you will not need more.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, my Case needs no more; but I think it incumbent on us all, to discountenance any Prosecution of our selves on any Account whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: To discountenance it by the Innocence of our Lives, is indeed laudable, but no farther. It is a cursed Law, which exempts the Maker, or the Executor of it, from its Penalty.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Truly, Brother Worthy, I think the Makers of Laws, and the Executors of them, should be free of them; as Authors and Actors are free of the Playhouse.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You are ludicrous, Mr. Squeezum. But let me tell you, he is the greatest of Villains, who hath the Impudence to hold the Sword of Justice, while he deserves its Edge.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: And let me tell you, Brother Worthy, he is the greatest of Fools, who holds the Sword of Justice, and hurts himself with it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Brother, your Servant; my Presence will be very little necessary at this Tryal.

div3.head: SCENE VII.
div3.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Constant, Hilaret, Staff, Sotmore, Brazencourt, Fireball, three Assistants.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: But here come the Prisoners—Brother Worthy, this is the Woman whom I accuse of this detestable Fact;—the Manner of it was this. I received a Letter in an unknown Hand, appointing me to meet at a Tavern, which out of pure Good-nature I comply'd with; and upon my Arrival found that Woman there alone, who after a short Discourse laid hold of me and bawl'd out, on which that Man there entered, and both threaten'd me, that unless I immediately discharged that Man [points to Const.] with another whom I had committed for notorious Crimes, that the Woman should swear a Rape against me—This I am ready to swear.—

sp.speaker: 1. 2. 3. Ass.
sp.p: And we are ready to swear.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What do you say, young Woman, to this? You do not look like one whom I should suspect of such a Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: That I did threaten him, as he says, indeed I confess.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But did he attempt any such thing?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I can't say he did, but—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do you hear this, Brother Worthy? I think you have nothing to do but to make her Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: And for what Reason did you offer this?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I offer'd it only to frighten him to the Discharge of two Gentlemen, whom he had villanously committed to the Custody of that Constable.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: For what Crimes do they stand committed, Mr. Constable?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: For two Rapes, an't please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: One of them on my Account—tho' I never swore the least thing against him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: On your Account,—I begin to be afraid he was unjustly committed indeed.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Now Sir, we shall proceed to blacken a little the Character of this Woman. Call Mr. Brazencourt; Mr. Brazencourt, what do you know of this fine Lady?

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: I know nothing more of her, than that I kept her half a Year.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Kept her!—in what Capacity did you keep her?

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: In the Capacity of a Whore, till I was obliged to turn her off, for stealing four of my Shirts, two pair of Stockings, and my Common-prayer Book.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Call Captain Fireball.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Captain Fireball, pray, do you know any Harm of that Person there?

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: Harm of her! ay, and so doth my Surgeon too. She came to me from Major Brazencourt. I kept her two Months.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: By and by. You must not interrupt them—Go on. Did you lose any thing by her too?

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: No, but I got something by her, which made my Surgeon get something by me—I love to express my self in modest Terms, but I believe you all know what I mean.

sp.speaker: Constant.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Call Mr. Drury. We shall blacken her farther presently.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Indeed, you need not; let us hear no more; for her sake, I will never put Confidence in an innocent Countenance again.—Well, Woman, can you say any thing for your self?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! that I could hide my self for ever from the World, and never from this Hour behold the Sun again.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Indeed but you shall, Madam, and be beheld by others too.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come to my Bosom, thou dearest, sweetest, loveliest, hide thy Sorrows there—Death only shall tear thee from my Arms again. Death, Hell it self cannot have a Torment equal to seeing one Tear of thine.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Heark'e, Justice, I believe thou art honester than thy Brother; I am sure thou canst not be a greater Rogue: If thou wilt act the right Part, acquit us, and send that Villain to Prison.

div3.head: SCENE VIII.
div3.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Constant, Hilaret, Sotmore, Staff, Constable, Assistants, Politick, Faithful, Cloris.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Now, Sir, will you believe your own Eyes?—Is not that your own Daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is indeed. O my unfortunate Child—

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, your humble Servant—I will but commit this Woman to Goal, and then I will be at your Command.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, you shall not be my humble Servant, nor will I be yours; and if you commit my Daughter to Prison, you are the worst of Turks.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Your Daughter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, my Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! my Father!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My poor Child!—That ever I should live to see thee in such a Misfortune!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Is it possible, Mr. Politick, that this young Lady is your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it is as possible, as that the Turks may come into our Part of Europe; and I wish this may not be as sure as that.

div3.head: SCENE IX.
div3.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Constant, Hilaret, Staff, Constables, Assistants, Politick, Faithful, Sotmore, Cloris, Ramble, Mrs. Squeezum, Quill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Where is this Glory of the Bench, this Gallant Justice? this Terror and Example of Sin? Do you know this Hand, Sir? Did you write this Assignation? You are a noble Gentleman truly, to make an Appointment with a fine Lady, and then bring her before a Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: O my malignat Stars!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mrs. Squeezum, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You Mr. Worthy, I am sure will pity one who hath the Misfortune to be married to a Man, who is as much a Scandal to the Commission he bears, as you are an Honour to it; my Conscience hath been too long burthened with conniving at his Rogueries. He, Sir, he alone is guilty, and every one whom he hath accused is innocent.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Sir, that Fellow there, that Butcher of Justice, is the greatest Villain that ever was born—Being a little frolicksome last Night with this Lady, that Constable seiz'd us. 'Tis to me she is indebted
for all this Trouble; tho' Mr. Constable may claim some Share, in not suffering us to depart at her Desire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: And Mr. Justice may claim a little, who committed you to the Constable's House without any Evidence, or even Accusation.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That he might extort two hundred Pounds, for which Sum he offered to compromise the Matter.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Heark'e, Madam, I shall be obliged to commit you to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: No, Sir, I shall prevent you in that, as well as in your other Designs; your Plot with Mr. Quill, which the whole World shall know; you shall be divorced, Sir, tho' not the Way you desire.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you to hear no more.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: That, Sir, I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sir, I desire that you would read that Letter, which he sent to this young Lady whom he hath accused.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: [Reads.] 'My little Honey-suckle, I will meet you within this half Hour at the Eagle. I hope after what you have received from me to-day, you will not disappoint yours till then and everafter.'—
Did you write this Letter, Mr. Squeezum?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: No, Sir, as I am ready to swear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, I will swear it to be his Hand—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: And so will I—I lived with him a Twelvemonth, and therefore should know it.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: And I carried it to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Come, come, Justice, thou hast Proof enough of her Innocence. I will give you the Word of a Man of Honour, which is more than the Oaths of twenty such Scoundrels as these, that she never intended more than to frighten him to the Acquittal of Captain Constant here, whom he had unjustly committed.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And offered to acquit for a Sum of Money.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Captain Constant! is your Name Constant, Sir?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: At your Service.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Desire my Sister to walk hither—I am more obliged to you than you know

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Come, Sir, this is only losing Time—I want the Mittimus.

div3.head: SCENE X.
div3.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Ramble, Constant, Sotmore, Hilaret, Politick, Mrs. Squeezum, Quill, Staff, Faithful, &c. Isabella.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sister, do you know this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Captain Constant! It is happy for me that I do—I thank you, Sir, for your generous Rescue last Night, which my Fright at that time prevented my acknowledging.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And was it you, Madam?—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Isabella!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ha!—it is, it is my Ramble—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Touch deceives me not, it is my charming She, once more restored to my despairing Hopes.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What lucky Stars can have contrived this Interview?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Very lucky Stars they appear now; but they had a confounded ugly Aspect some time ago.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Surprizing! Brother, let that Fellow be secured. He was the Person from whose Hands this Gentleman delivered me.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: I hope your Worship will forgive me; but I hir'd these two Men, by my Master's Command, to be Evidences for him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Surprizing Villany!—secure them instantly. And particularly that Justice,—whom I shall no longer treat as a Gentleman, but as his Villany hath merited—Constable, I charge you with them all—and let them be kept below in the Parlour, whither I will come immediately and sign their Commitment.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, you shall wish you had dealt more favourably with me.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sir, your Threatnings will not terrifie me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, we'll be your Safe-guard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I'll follow thee, like thy evil Genius, till I have brought thee to that Justice thou deservest.

div3.head: SCENE the Last.
div3.stage: Worthy, Ramble, Conant, Sotmore, Hilaret, Isabella, Politick.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My dear Isabella, I am so overjoyed at this unexpected Meeting, that I do not ask for the Safety of our Treasure. Since the Sea hath refunded Isabella, let it take the Jewels.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The Sea hath been even kinder than your Wish, it hath return'd you both.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I should have soon forgotten that Loss, in having Isabella; yet for her sake, the Teasure is welcome too.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, I am heartily concerned at this Misfortune which hath befallen your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Mr. Politick!—By Heavens, his Features are the same. Had you not a Son, Sir, once?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I had; but I turn'd him out of Doors, and believe he was hanged long ago.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then I am his Ghost, just arrived from the Indies. When you turn'd me out of Doors, I got admitted into the East-India Company's Service; I changed my Name in order to escape your Discovery—and I hope you will now give us both your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And are you really that wild Follow my Son?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am that very identical wild Person, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I don't know whether I'll give you my Blessing or no, till I see how you are married.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, I rejoice in the Union of our Families; this Lady, your Son's Wife, is my Sister—and if fourscore thousand Pounds can make the Match agreeable to you, it will be so.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hath the wild Rogue made his Fortune at last! Well, Son, I give you my Blessing; and my dear Daughter I give you Joy, and I hope the Boy will give it you, ay, and lasting constant Joy—If he doth not make you a good Husband, I'll not own him; if he doth not make you blessed, he shall have no Blessing of mine.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Sir, I doubt him not.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, Father, I have nothing more to ask of you, but in Favour of my Friend Captain Constant, whose Love I am certain will compleat the Happiness of my Sister.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I think I have never been witness to such a Complication of Villany. Sir, [to Constant] I assure you, and all of you, you shall have sufficient Reparaton for the Injuries you have suffer'd. And Sir, by the Characters which I have had from my Sister of that Gentleman, I do not think your Daughter can be better disposed of, let the Difference of Fortune be what it please.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Besides, tho' his Estate be not equal now, it may become so; for no Man hath a better Insight into Politicks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, if his Studies bend that Way, no Man indeed can tell to what his Estate may come—Had I known this sooner, my Doors should never have been shut against him. Sir, I shall be glad to confabulate with you at my House—and if you should set your Heart on my Daughter, I do not believe I shall do any thing to break it.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, there is no Hour like the Present: This Hour hath proved lucky to your Family—Give me leave to present your Daughter to one whom if she deserves, I shall be proud of calling her Sister.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ramble, you have crown'd my Obligations with a Gift, far dearer than the Earth could prove.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
I only wish you may always think so, Captain. And now, Pappa, I hope you will pardon this Night's Sally, to both me and poor Cloris; we have been already
sufficiently punished; and since the Event is happpy, imitate in this one thing the Turks, and consider it favourably, as it hath been prosperous.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: The Turks! I wish you were better acquainted with them than in Romances; I hope that Gentleman will take care to instruct you in publick Affairs.—Well Jack [to Ramble] I long to have some Communication with you about the Affairs of the Indies, and the Posture of our Trade there—I hope you left the Great Mogul in good Health—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Very slightly indisposed of a Cold at my Departure.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I heartily forgive you all: So let me see you all embrace one another—This is the Comfort of Age, Mr. Worthy.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Let me embrace you all together—I have found this Day two good Women—and they have fallen to the Share of my Friends—and I will get drunk this Night, if the Spirit of Wine will do it—I'll drink to your Happiness, while you are enjoying it—While you are tasting the Joys of Venus, I will swallow down the Delights of Bacchus—I despair of either of your Company this Month yet—but the Justice shall celebrate this Night with me—Come, honest Justice—I have found one honest Justice too—

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Really, Sir, I think you have sufficiently celebrated already—

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: No, but I have not—and you, Sir, will be drunk at your Children's Wedding-Night.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I never drink any thing but Coffee, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Damn your Coffee—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sotmore, thou shalt have Justice—Mr. Worthy, I assure you, notwithstanding this Humour, the World hath not an honester Man.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p:
It is pity he should besot himself so. Your Character of him encourages me to employ some Labour in advising him, to quit so beastly a Pleasure.—Come Gentlemen, I desire you would celebrate this Day at my House to-morrow. I will proceed to take
all possible Measures to your receiving Satisfaction for your Injuries, and making publick Example of so great a Villain: for the Crimes of a Magistrate give the greatest Sanction to Sin.
sp.l: No Reverence that Church or State attends,
Whose Laws the Priest or Magistrate offends.
